docTitle.titlePart: THE GREAT ADVENTURE A Play of Fancy in Four Acts by ARNOLD BENNETT

list.item: ACT I ROOM IN ILAM CARVE 'S HOUSE , 126 REDCLIFFE GARDENS
ACT II PRIVATE ROOM AT THE GRAND BABYLON HOTEL
ACT III JANET 'S SITTING-ROOM AT WERTER ROAD , PUTNEY

ACT IV LORD LEONARD ALCAR 'S STUDY , GROSVENOR GARDENS SPECIAL NOTE .— Each Act is divided into two scenes , separated by a passage of time more or less short . The passage of time is indicated by darkening the stage for a few moments . No change of scenery is involved . NOTE

titlePage.docImprint: The play was produced for the first time inLondonat the Kingsway Theatre , by Granville Barker , on Tuesday , March 25th ,1913.

div.head: SCENE I

stage.stage: Front room on ground floor at 126 Redcliffe Gardens . An apartment furnished richly but in an old-fashioned way . Fine pictures . Large furniture . Sofa near centre . General air of neglect and dustiness . Carpet half-laid . Trunks and bags lying about in corners , some opened . Men 's wearing apparel exposed . Mantelpiece , R ., in disorder . At back double doors ( ajar ) leading to another room . Door , L ., leading to hall and front door .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — Evening in August . ALBERT SHAWN is reclining on the sofa , fully dressed , but obviously ill : an overcoat has been drawn over his legs . A conspicuous object is a magnificent light purple dressing-gown thrown across a chair . Door bangs off . Enter ILAM CARVE in his shirt sleeves , hurriedly . SHAWN feebly tries to get up .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now , do n't move . Remember you 're a sick man , and forget you 're a servant .

div.stage: SHAWN shivers . CARVE , about to put on his dressing-gown , changes his mind , and wraps it round SHAWN as well as he can . CARVE then puts on an oldish coat .

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: Feebly .You 've been very quick , sir .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I found a red lamp only three doors off . He 'll be along in half a minute .

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: Did you explain what it was , sir ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Genially .How could I explain what it was , you fool , when I do n't know ? I simply asked to see the doctor , and I told him there was a fellow-creature suffering at No . 126 , and would he come at once . “ 126 ? ” he said , “ 126 has been shut up for years . ”

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: Trying to smile .What did you say , sir ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I saidarticulating with clearnessa hundred and twenty-six — and ran off . Then he yelled out after me that he 'd come instantly .... I say , Shawn , we 're discovered . I could tell that from his sudden change of tone . I bet the entire street knows that the celebrated Me has arrived at last . I feel like a criminal already , dashed if I do n't ! I wish we 'd gone to a hotel now .Walks about .I say , did you make up the bed ?

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: I was just doing it , sir .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But what about sheets and so on ?

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: I bought some this morning , ready hemmed , sir — with those and the travelling rug ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , do n't you think you could work your passage out to the bed ? With my help ?

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: Me in your bed , sir !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Genially bullying .Keep on in that tone — and I 'll give you the sack on the spot . Now then . Try — before the doctor comes .Bell rings .

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: The bell , sir — excuse me .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Confound ——

div.stage: Exit CARVE .
SHAWN coughs and puts a handkerchief to his mouth . CARVE returns immediately with DR. PASCOE .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Glancing round quickly .This the patient ?Goes to SHAWN , and looks at him . Then , taking a clinical thermometer from his pocket and wiping it ; with marked respect .Allow me to put this under your tongue for half a minute .Having done so , he takes SHAWN 'S wrist and , looking at his watch , counts the patient 's pulse . Then turning to CARVE , in a low curt voicedWhen did this begin ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Just now . That is , he only began to complain about six o'clock . We arrived in London this morning from Madrid .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Reading thermometer .Temperature 104-1 / 2 . Pulse is 140 — and weak . I must have some boiling water .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: At a loss .What for ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: What for ? For a poultice .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Helplessly .But there is n't any ... we 've nothing except this spirit-lamp .Pointing to lamp on table .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: No women in the house ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With humour that the doctor declines to see .Not one .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Controlling his exasperation .Never mind . I 'll run round to the surgery and get my hypodermic .To SHAWN , reassuringly and deferentially .I shall be back at once , Mr . Carve .To CARVE , near door .Keep your master well covered up — I suppose you can do that ?

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shawn , my poor fellow , he takes you for the illustrious Ilam Carve . This is what comes of me rushing out in shirt sleeves .Gesture of despair .I can n't explain it to him .

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: But ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's all right . You 'll be infinitely better looked after , you know , and I shall be saved from their infernal curiosity .

sp.speaker: SHAWN
sp.p: It 's only this , sir . I was half-expecting a young lady to-night , sirvery feeblyAt least , I believe she 's young .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shawn , I 've always suspected you were a bad lot . Now I know . I also know why you were so devilish anxious to put me to bed early . What am I to say to this young lady on your behalf ?

div.stage: SHAWN worse , too ill to answer . Pause . Re-enter DR. PASCOE , very rapidly , with a large tumbler half-full of hot liquid .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: You may say I 've been quick .As he bends down to SHAWN , addressing CARVE .Get me a wine glass of clean cold water .To SHAWN .Now , please . I want you to drink a little brandy and water .SHAWN makes no response .By Jove !The doctor pours some of the brandy and water down SHAWN 'S throat .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Who has been wandering about vaguely .I do n't think we 've got a wine glass . There 's a cup , but I suppose that is n't medical enough .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Taking a syringe from his pocket and unscrewing it .Pour some water in it .CARVE obeys .Now , hold it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Indicating syringe .What is this device ? PASCOE . This device ? I 'm going to get some strychnine into him by injection . Steady with that cup , now !

div.stage: Pascoe drops a tablet into the syringe and screws it up again , draws a little water up into the syringe and shakes the syringe . Then he goes to SHAWN to make the injection , on the top side of the patient 's forearm . CARVE still holds the cup out mechanically .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: I 've done with that cup .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Putting the cup down .Might I ask what 's the matter with him ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Pneumonia is the matter .

div.stage: Noise of some one in the hall .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Startled .Surely that 's some one in the hall .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Keep perfectly calm , my man . It 's my assistant . I left the door open on purpose for him . He 's got the poultice and things .In a loud voice as he finishes the injection .Come along , come along there . This way .

div.stage: Enter EDWARD HORNING with poultice , lint , bandages , etc . ) PASCOE . Found the antiphlogistine ?

lg.l: Yes .
lg.stage: He looks at patient , and exchanges a glance with PASCOE .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Where 's the bedroom ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: There 's one there .Pointing to double doors .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: To HORNING .We 'll get him into bed now .To CARVE .Bed ready ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . I — I think he was just making it up .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Startled .Does he make up his own bed ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Perceiving the mistake , but resuming his calm .Always .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Controlling his astonishment ; looking through double doors and opening them wider . To HORNING .Yes , this will do . Put those things down here a minute while we lift him .

div.stage: PASCOE and HORNING then carry the inanimate form of SHAWN into the room behind , while CARVE hovers about uselessly .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Can I do anything ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Indicating a chair furthest away from the double doors .You see that chair ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I see it .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Go and sit on it .

div.stage: Exeunt PASCOE and HORNING , back , closing double door 's .

After walking about , CARVE sits down on another chair . A bell rings twice . He pays no attention . Then enter JANET CANNOT , L. CARVE jumps up , but is inarticulate , though very favourably interested .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Smiling sympathetically .I rang twice .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The bell must be out of order .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I could n't be sure , but I do n't think it 's the bell that 's out of order .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh ! You think I 'm out of order .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No . I was thinking that you 'd only just come into the house — all you famous folk — and you had n't quite got it straight yet — as it were .Looking vaguely at room .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: All we famous folk ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well — I do n't know myself about that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What sort of thing ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Picture-painting , is n't it ? I mean real pictures done by hand , coloured —— CARVE . Ah — yes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: After a slight pause .It struck me all of a sudden , while I was waiting at the door , that it might have been left open on purpose .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The front door ? On purpose ? What for ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh — for some one particular to walk in without any fuss . So in I stepped .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 're the young lady that Mr. Shawn 's expecting ——Going towards passage .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stopping him .It 's shut now . You do n't want everybody walking in , do you ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Looking at JANET with pleasure .So you 're the young lady — Mrs .— Miss ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Ignoring his question .Was it a message you had for me ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , no . Not a message .... But — the fact is , we 're rather upset here for the moment .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes . Illness .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now , if it is n't an indiscreet question , how did you know that there was illness ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I was standing looking at this house and wondering whether I should n't do better to go right back home there and then . But “ No , ” I said , “ I 've begun , and I 'll go through with it . ” — Well , I was standing there when what should I see but a parlour maid pop up from the area steps next door , and she says to me over the railings , “ The doctor 's just been . ” Just like that , excited . So I said , “ Thank you , miss . ” I hope it 's nothing serious ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Pneumonia .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Pneumonia . What a mercy !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Mercy ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: If you look at it sensibly it 's about the best illness anybody could have in hot weather like this . You 've got to keep them warm . The weather does it for you . If it was typhoid now , and you 'd got to keep them cool — that would be awkward . Not but it passes me how anybody can catch pneumonia in August .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Coming over from the Continent .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh ! the Continent . It 's not Mr. Shawn that 's ill ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Hesitating .Mr. Shawn ? Oh no , no ! It 's Ilam Carve .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Half whispering . Awed .Oh , him ! Poor thing . And nobody but men in the house .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And who told you that ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well !waves her hand to indicate the state of the room , smiling indulgentlyI always feel sorry for gentlemen when they have to manage for themselves , even if they 're well and hearty . But when it comes to illness — I can n't bear to think about it . Still , everybody has their own notions of comfort . And I 've no doubt he 'll very soon be better .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You think he will ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Blandly cheerful .As a general rule , you may say that people do get better . That 's my experience . Of course sometimes they take a longish time . And now and then one dies — else what use would cemeteries be ? But as a general rule they 're soon over it . Now am I going to see Mr. Shawn , or shall I ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , if you could call again ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You say you had n't a message ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Not precisely a message . But if you could call again ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: When ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Rather eagerly .Any time . Any time . Soon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Night after to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why not morning ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Perhaps morning is safer . Thank you . Very well , then . Day after to-morrow .... I suppose Mr. Shawn has a rare fine situation here ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .Nothing to complain of , if you ask me .

div.stage: JANET offers her hand quite simply . The double doors open , CARVE looks alarmed .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Thank you very much . I think I can open the front door myself .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I say — you wo n't forget ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , what do you think ?

div.stage: Exit , L .
Enter DR. PASCOE through double doors .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: At double doors , to HORNING invisible behind .Then there 's no reason why the nurse at Edith Grove should n't come along here .

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Off .Yes . She 'll be free in an hour .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: All right . I 'll look in there .

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Nervous .What am I to do if his respiration ——

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Interrupting .Do n't worry . I 'm not gone yet . I must just clean up my hypodermic . Shut those doors .

div.stage: HORNING obeys .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What 's this about a nurse ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Busy with syringe , water , and syringe-case .I 'm sending one in .Ironically .Do you see any objection ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: On the contrary , I should like him to be treated with every care . He 's invaluable to me .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Staggered .Invaluable to you ! Of course in my line of business I get used to meeting odd people ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Recovering from his mistake .But you think I carry oddness rather far ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: The idea did pass through my mind .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Nervousness — nothing but nervousness . I 'm very nervous . And then — you know the saying — like master , like man .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Indicating back room with a gesture ; in a slightly more confidential tone as CARVE 'S personal attractiveness gains on him .Mr . Carve odd ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , very . Always was . Ever since I 've known him . You remember his first picture at the Academy ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: No , not exactly .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Either you remember it exactly or you do n't remember it at all . Life-size picture of a policeman blowing his whistle .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Yes ; it must have been odd , that must .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Not a bit . The oddness of the fellow ——

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: What ‘ fellow ’ — your governor ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Nods .His oddness came out in this way — although the thing had really a great success , from that day to this he 's never painted another life-size picture of a policeman blowing his whistle .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: I do n't see anything very odd there ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Do n't you ? Well , perhaps you do n't go in for art much . If you did , you 'd know that the usual and correct thing for a painter who has made a great success with a life-size picture of a policeman blowing his whistle , is to keep on doing life-size pictures of a policeman blowing his whistle for ever and ever , so that the public can always count on getting from him a life-size picture of a policeman blowing his whistle .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: I observe you are one of those comic valets . Nervousness again , no doubt .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Smiling and continuing .Seeing the way he invariably flouted the public , it 's always been a mystery to me how he managed to make a name , to say nothing of money .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Money ! He must make pots . You say I do n't go in for art much , but I always read the big sales at Christie 's . Why , was n't it that policeman picture that Lord Leonard Alcar bought for 2000 guineas last year ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , not Alcar . I think the bobby was last bought by Texel .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Texel ? Who 's Texel ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Collector — United States — one of their kings , I 'm told .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Oh , him ! Controls all the ink in the United States .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Really ! That 's what I should call influence . No . It was the “ Pelicans feeding their Young ” that Alcar bought . Four thousand . You 're getting mixed up .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Perhaps I am . I know I 'm constantly seeing Mr . Carve 's name in connection with Lord Leonard Alcar 's . It 's a nice question which is the best known of the two .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Then the — governor really is famous in England ? You see we never come to England .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Famous — I should think he was . Are n't they always saying he 's the finest colourist since Titian ? And look at his prices !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . I 've looked at his prices . Titian 's prices are higher , but Titian is n't what you 'd call famous with the general public , is he ? What I want to know is — is the governor famous among the general public ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: About how famous should you say he is ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Hesitating .Well —abruptlythat 's a silly question .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , it is n't . Is he as famous as — er — Harry Lauder ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Shakes his head .You must n't go to extremes .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Is he as famous as Harry Vardon ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Never heard of him .

lg.l: I only see these names in the papers . Is he as famous as Bernard
Shaw ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Yes , I should say he was .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , well that 's not so bad . Better than I thought ! It 's so difficult to judge where one is — er — personally concerned . Especially if you 're never on the spot .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: So it 's true Mr . Carve never comes to England ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why should he come to England ? He is n't a portrait painter . It 's true he owns this house , but surely that is n't sufficient excuse for living in a place like England ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Of course , if you look at it like that , there 's no particular attractiveness in England that I 've ever seen . But that answer would n't satisfy Redcliffe Gardens . Redcliffe Gardens is persuaded that there must be a special reason .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , there is .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Interested , in spite of himself .Indeed !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Confidentially .Have a cigarette ?Offering case .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Staggered anew , but accepting .That 's a swagger case .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh !Calmly .He gave it me .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , you see we 're more like brothers — been together so long . He gives me his best suits too . Look at this waistcoat .Motions the hypnotised PASCOE to take a chair . They light their cigarettes .

div.stage: Enter HORNING .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Somewhat impatient .He 's not worse already ?

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Where 's that brandy and water ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Be careful . He 's had about enough of that .

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Seeing I 've had no dinner yet — I thought it might suit me .Exit with tumbler .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: To Carve with renewed eagerness .So there is a special reason why you keep out of England .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes — shyness .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: How — shyness ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Just simple shyness . Shyness is a disease with the governor , a perfect disease .

lg.l: But everyone 's shy . The more experience I get the more convinced
I am that we 're all shy . Why , you were shy when you came to fetch me !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Did you notice it ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Of course . And I was shy when I came in here . I was thinking to myself , “ Now I 'm going to see the great Ilam Carve actually in the flesh , ” and I was shy . You 'd think my profession would have cured me of being shy , but not a bit . Nervous disease , of course ! Ought to be treated as such . Almost universal . Besides , even if he is shy , your governor — even if he 's a hundredfold shy , that 's no reason for keeping out of England . Shyness is not one of those diseases you can cure by change of climate .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Pardon me . My esteemed employer 's shyness is a special shyness . He 's only shy when he has to play the celebrity . So long as people take him for no one in particular he 's quite all right . For instance , he 's never shy with me . But instantly people approach him as the celebrity , instantly he sees in the eye of the beholder any consciousness of being in the presence of a toff — then he gets desperately shy , and his one desire is to be alone at sea or to be buried somewhere deep in the bosom of the earth .PASCOE laughs .What are you laughing at ?CARVE also laughs .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Go on , go on . I 'm enjoying it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , but seriously ! It 's true what I tell you . It amounts almost to a tragedy in the brilliant career of my esteemed . You see now that England would be impossible for him as a residence . You see , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why , even on the Continent , in the big towns and the big hotels , we often travel incognito for safety . It 's only in the country districts that he goes about under his own name .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: So that he 's really got no friends ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: None , except a few Italian and Spanish peasants — and me .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Well , well ! It 's an absolute mania then , this shyness .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Slightly hurt .Oh , not so bad as that ! And then it 's only fair to say he has his moments of great daring — you may say rashness .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: All timid people are like that .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Are they ?Musing .We 're here now owing to one of his moments of rashness .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Indeed !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . We met an English lady in a village in Andalusia , and — well , of course , I can n't tell you everything — but she flirted with him and he flirted with her .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Under his own name ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . And then he proposed to her . I knew all along it was a blunder .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Ironic .Did you ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . She belonged to the aristocracy , and she was one of those amateur painters that wander about the Continent by themselves — you know .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: And did she accept ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh yes . They got as far as Madrid together , and then all of a sudden my esteemed saw that he had made a mistake .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: And what then ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: We fled the country . We hooked it . The idea of coming to London struck him — just the caprice of a man who 's lost his head — and here we are .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: After a pause .He does n't seem to me from the look of him to be a man who 'd — shall we say ?— strictly avoided women .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Startled , with a gesture towards back .Him ?PASCOE nods .Really ! Confound him ! Now I 've always suspected that ; though he manages to keep his goings-on devilish quiet .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Rising .It occurs to me , my friend , that I 'm listening to too much . But you 're so persuasive .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's such a pleasure to talk freely — for once in a way .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Freely — is the word .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh ! He wo n't mind !

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: In a peculiar tone .It 's quite possible !

div.stage: Enter HORNING .

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: To Carve .I say , it 's just occurred to me , Mr . Carve has n't been digging or gardening or anything , I suppose , and then taken cold after ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Digging ? Oh no . He must have got a bad chill on the steamer . Why ?

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Nothing . Only his hands and finger-nails are so rough .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After thinking .Oh , I see ! All artists are like that . Messing about with paints and acids and things . Look at my hands .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: But are you an artist too ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Recovering himself , calmly .No , no .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: To Horning .How 's he going on ?

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: Shrugs his shoulders .I 'm sure the base of both lungs is practically solid .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Well , we can n't do more than we have done , my boy .

sp.speaker: HORNING
sp.p: He 'll never pull through .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Calmly .I should certainly be surprised if he did .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Astounded .But — but ——

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: But what ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You do n't mean to say — Why , he 's a strong healthy man !

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Precisely . Not very unusual for your strong healthy man to die of pneumonia in twenty-four hours . You ought to know , at your age , that it 's a highly dangerous thing to be strong and healthy .Turning away .I 'll have another look at him before I go .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Extremely perturbed .But this is ridiculous . I simply do n't know what I shall do without that man . The stage is darkened for a few moments to indicate passage of time .

div.head: SCENE 2

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — The next morning but one . Slightly less disorder in the room . CARVE and PASCOE are together , the latter ready to leave .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Will there have to be an inquest ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Inquest ? Of course not .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's some relief to know that . I could n't have faced a coroner .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Staring at him .Perfectly ordinary case .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That 's what you call perfectly ordinary , is it ? A man is quite well on Tuesday afternoon , and dead at 4 a. m. on Thursday morning .Looking at his watch .My watch has stopped .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: With fierce sarcasm .One of those cheap German watches , I suppose , that stop when you do n't wind them up ! It 's a singular thing that when people stay up all night they take it for granted their watches are just as excited as they are . Look here , you 'll be collapsing soon . When did you have anything to eat last ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Almost half an hour ago . Two sausages that were sent in yesterday for the nurse .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: She 's gone ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh yes .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Well , take my advice . Try to get some sleep now . You 've had no reply from the relatives — the auctioneer cousin — what 's his Christian name — Cyrus ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , I — I did n't telegraph — I forgot ——

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Well , upon my soul ! I specially reminded you yesterday afternoon .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I did n't know the address .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Ever heard of the London Directory ? You 'd better run out and wire instantly . You do n't seem to realize that the death of a man like Ilam Carve will make something of a stir in the world . And you may depend on it that whether they 'd quarrelled or not , Cyrus Carve will want to know why he was n't informed of the illness at once . You 've let yourself in for a fine row , and well you deserve it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After a few paces .See here , doctor . I 'm afraid there 's been some mistake .Facing him nervously .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: What ? CARVE . I — I ——

div.stage: Bell rings .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Firmly .Listen to me , my man . There 's been no sort of mistake . Everything has been done that could be done . Do n't you get ideas into your head . Lie down and rest . You 're done up , and if you are n't careful you 'll be ill . I 'll communicate with Cyrus Carve . I can telephone , and while I 'm about it I 'll ring up the registrar too — he 'll probably send a clerk round .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Registrar ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Registrar of deaths . There 'll be all kinds of things to attend to .Moving to go out .

div.stage: Bell rings again .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: As if dazed .Is that the front door bell ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Drily .Quite possibly ! I 'll open it .

div.stage: Exit .
CARVE , alone , makes a gesture of despair . Re-enter PASCOE with CYRUS CARVE .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: As they enter .Yes , very sudden , very sudden . There were three of us — a nurse , my assistant , and myself . This is Mr. Shawn , the deceased 's valet .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Morning .Looks round at disorder of room contemptuously .Pigstye !... My name is Cyrus Carve . I 'm your late master 's cousin and his only relative . You 've possibly never heard of me .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Curtly .Oh yes , I have ! You got up a great quarrel when you were aged twelve , you and he .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Your manner is n't very respectful , my friend . However you may have treated my cousin , be good enough to remember you 're not my valet .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: How did you get to know about it ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: I suppose he forbade you to send for me , eh ?Pause .Eh ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jumping at this suggestion .Yes .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: So that was it .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Ignoring PASCOE .Ha ! Well , since you 're so curious , I saw it a quarter of an hour ago in a special edition of a halfpenny rag ; I was on my way to the office .Showing paper .Here you are ! The Evening Courier . Quite a full account of the illness . You could n't send for me , but you could chatter to some journalist .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've never spoken to a journalist in my life .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Then how ——?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: It 's probably my assistant . His brother is something rather important on the Courier , and he may have telephoned to him . It 's a big item of news , you know , Mr . Carve .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Drily .I imagine so . Where is the body ?

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Upstairs .Moving towards door .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Thanks . I will go alone .

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: Large room at back — first floor .Exit CYRUS , L .I think I 'd prefer to leave you to yourselves now . Of course , Mr . Carve will do all that 's necessary . You might give him my card , and tell him I 'm at his service as regards signing the death certificate and so on .Handing card .

lg.l: Very well . Then you 're going ?
PASCOE . Yes .
lg.stage: Moves away and then suddenly puts out his hand , which CARVE takes .
lg.l: Want a word of advice ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I — I ought ——

sp.speaker: PASCOE
sp.p: If I were you I should try to get something better than valeting . It 's not your line . You may have suited Ilam Carve , but you 'd never suit an ordinary employer . You are n't a fool — not by any means .

div.stage: CARVE shrugs his shoulders .
Exit PASCOE , L. Door shuts off .
Re-enter CYRUS immediately after the door shuts .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: To himself .Now for it !To CYRUSWell ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Well what ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Recognize your cousin ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Of course a man of forty-five is n't like a boy of twelve , but I think I may say I should have recognized him anywhere .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Taken aback .Should you indeed .A pause .And so you 're Cyrus , the little boy that kicked and tried to bite in that historic affray of thirty years ago .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Look here , I fancy you and I had better come to an understanding at once . What salary did my cousin pay you for your remarkable services ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What salary ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: What salary ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Eighty pounds a year .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: When were you last paid ? CARVE . I — I ——

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: When were you last paid ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The day before yesterday .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Taking a note and gold from his pocket-book and pocket .Here 's seven pounds — a month 's wages in lieu of notice . It 's rather more than a month 's wages , but I can n't do sums in my head just now .Holding out money .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But listen ——

lg.l: Take it .
Pack up and be out of this house within an hour .
CARVE . I ——

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: I shall not argue .... Did your master keep his private papers and so on in England or somewhere on the Continent — what bank ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What bank ? He did n't keep them in any bank .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Where did he keep them then ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: He kept them himself .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: What — travelling ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . Why not ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: With a “ tut-tut ” noise to indicate the business man 's mild scorn of the artist 's method 's .Whose is this luggage ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Mine .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: All of it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That is ——

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Come now , is it his or is it yours ? Now be careful .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: His .Angrily , as CYRUS roughly handles a box .Now then , mind what you 're about ! Those are etching things .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: I shall mind what I 'm about . And what 's this ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That 's a typewriter .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: I always thought artists could n't stand typewriting machines .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That was — his servant 's .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Yours , you mean ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , I mean mine .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Then why do n't you say so ? What do you want a typewriter for ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Savagely .What the devil has that got to do with you ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Looking up calmly from the examination of a dispatch box .If you can n't keep a civil tongue in your head I 'll pitch you down the front-door steps and your things after you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've got something to tell you ——

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Silence , and answer my questions ! Are his papers in this dispatch box ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Where are his keys ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Slowly drawing bunch of keys from his pocket .Here .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Taking them .So you keep his keys ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Opening dispatch box .Wear his clothes too , I should say !

div.stage: CARVE sits down negligently and smiles .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: As he is examining papers in box .What are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'm not laughing . I 'm smiling .Rising and looking curiously at box .There 's nothing there except lists of securities and pictures and a few oddments — passports and so on .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: There appears to be some money . I 'm glad you 've left that . Quite a lot , in fact .Showing notes .

lg.l: Here , steady ! There 's twelve thousand francs there besides some
English notes . That 's mine .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Yours , eh ? He was taking care of it for you , no doubt ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Hesitating .Yes .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: When you can furnish me with his receipt for the deposit , my man , it shall be handed to you . Till then it forms part of the estate .Looking at a packet of letters .“ Alice Rowfant . ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And those letters are mine too .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Reading .“ My dearest boy ” — Were you Lady Alice Rowfant 's dearest boy ? Anyhow , we 'll burn them .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: So long as you burn them I do n't mind .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Indeed !Continues to examine papers , cheque foils , etc . Then opens a document .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh ! Is that still there ? I thought it was destroyed .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Do you know what it is ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . It 's a will that was made in Venice I do n't know how long ago — just after your aunt died and you had that appalling and final shindy by correspondence about the lease of this house . Everything is left for the establishment of an International Gallery of Painting and Sculpture in London , and you 're the sole executor , and you get a legacy of five pounds for your trouble .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Yes .... So I see . No doubt my cousin imagined it would annoy me .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: He did .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: He told you so ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: He said it would be one in the eye for you — and he wondered whether you 'd decline the executorship .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Well , my man , I may tell you at once that I shall not renounce probate . I never expected a penny from my cousin . I always assumed he 'd do something silly with his money , and I 'm relieved to find it 's no worse . In fact , the idea of a great public institution in London being associated with my family is rather pleasant .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But he meant to destroy that will long since .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: As he cons the will .How do you know ? Has he made a later will ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Well , then ! Besides , I fail to see why you should be so anxious to have it destroyed . You come into eighty pounds a year under it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I was forgetting that .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Reading .“ I bequeath to my servant , Albert Shawn , who I am convinced is a thorough rascal , but who is an unrivalled valet , courier , and factotum , the sum of eighty pounds a year for life , payable quarterly in advance , provided he is in my service at the time of my death . ”CARVE laughs shortly .You do n't want to lose that , do you ? Of course , if the term “ thorough rascal ” is offensive to you , you can always decline the money .Folds up will and puts it in his pocket — CARVE walks about .Now where 's the doctor ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: He 's left his card . There it is .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: He might have waited .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . But he did n't . His house is only three doors off .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Looking at his watch .I 'll go in and see him about the certificate . Now you have n't begun to put your things together , and you 've only got a bit over half an hour . In less than that time I shall be back . I shall want to look through your luggage before you leave .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lightly .Shall you ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: By the way , you have a latchkey ?CARVE nods .Give it me , please .

div.stage: CARVE surrenders latchkey .
CYRUS turns to go — As he is disappearing through the door , L ., CARVE starts forward .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I say .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: What now ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Subsiding weakly .Nothing .

div.stage: Exit CYRUS . Sound of front door opening and of voices in hall .
Then re-enter CYRUS with JANET CANNOT .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: This is Mr. Albert Shawn . Shawn , a friend of yours .

div.stage: Exit L .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Pleased .Oh ! You !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Good-morning . D'you know , I had a suspicion the other night that you must be Mr. Shawn ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Had you ? Well , will you sit down — er — I saywith a humorous mysterious airWhat do you think of that chap ?Pointing in direction of hall .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Who is it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's Mr. Cyrus Carve . The great West End auctioneer .

div.stage: Sound of front-door shutting rather too vigorously .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I see no reason why he should look at me as if I 'd insulted him .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Did he ?

lg.l: “ Good-morning , ” I said to him . “ Excuse me , but are you Mr. Albert
Shawn ? ” Because I was n't sure , you know . And he looked .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After laughing .The man is an ass .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Is he ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Not content with being an ass merely , he is a pompous and a stupid ass .Laughs again to himself .Now there is something very important that he ought to know , and he would n't let me tell him . JANET . Really ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , very important . But no . He would n't let me tell him . And perhaps if I 'd told him he would n't have believed me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What did he do to stop you from telling him ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: At a loss , vaguely .I do n't know — Would n't let me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: If you ask me , I should say the truth is , you did n't want to tell him .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Impressed .Now I wonder if you 're right .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I do n't quite see how anybody can stop anybody from talking . But even if he did , he can n't stop you from writing to him .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , I 'm hanged if I write to him !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , well , that 's a proof you did n't want to tell him .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Perhaps it is .After a burst of quiet laughter .Pardon me .Reflective .I was only thinking what a terrific lark it will be .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: If he never does get to know ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: If he never does get to know . If nobody ever gets to know .Resolved .No . I 'll keep my mouth shut .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: As a general rule , it 's the best thing to do .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You advise me to keep my mouth shut ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Not at all . I simply say , as a general rule it 's the best thing to do . But this is no business of mine , and I 'm sure I 'm not inquisitive .

lg.l: He shall go his own way .
And
I 'll — go — mine .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Calmly indifferent .That 's settled , then .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Laughs again to himself , then controls his features .And that being settled , the first thing I have to do is to apologize for my behaviour on Tuesday night .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , not at all . Seeing how upset you were ! And then I 'm not sure whether I should n't have done the same thing myself in your place .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Done the same yourself ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I may be wrong , but it occurred to me your idea was that you 'd like to have a look at me before giving yourself away , as it were . Of course , I sent you my photographs , but photographs are n't much better than gravestones — for being reliable , and some folks are prejudiced against matrimonial agencies , even when they make use of them . It 's natural . Now I 've got no such prejudice . If you want to get married you want to get married , and there you are . It 's no use pretending you do n't . And there 's as much chance of being happy through a matrimonial agency as any other way . At least — that 's what I think .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Collecting his wits .Just so .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You may tell me that people who go to a matrimonial agency stand a chance of getting let in . Well , people who do n't go to a matrimonial agency stand a chance of getting let in , too . Besides , I should n't give a baby a razor for a birthday present , and I should n't advise a young girl to go to a matrimonial agency . But I 'm not a young girl . If it 's a question of the male sex , I may say that I 've been there before . You understand me ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I think I told you pretty nearly everything important in my letter . Did n't I ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Let me see now ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I mean the one I sent to the office of the Matrimonial News .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Mechanically feeling in his pockets , pulling out papers and putting them back .Where did I put it ? Oh , perhaps it 's in the pocket of another coat .Goes to a coat of SHAWN 'S hanging on inner knob of double doors , and empties all the pockets , bringing the contents , including a newspaper , to the table .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Picking up an envelope .Yes , that 's it — I can feel the photograph . You seem to keep things in the pockets of all your coats .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: If you knew what I 've been through this last day or two ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Soothingly .Yes , yes .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I have n't had a quiet moment . Now ——Reading letter .“ Dear Sir , in reply to your advertisement , I write to you with particulars of my case . I am a widow , aged thirty-two years —— ”

lg.l: And anybody that likes can see my birth certificate . That 's what
I call talking .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: My dear lady !Continuing to read .“ Thirty-two years . My father was a jobbing builder , well known in Putney and Wandsworth . My husband was a rent collector and estate agent . He died four years ago of appendicitishesitatingcaught —— ”

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Caused .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I beg pardon , “ — caused by accidentally swallowing a bristle out of his tooth-brush , the same being discovered at the operation . I am an orphan , a widow , and have no children . In consequence I feel very lonely , and my first experience not being distasteful , indeed the reverse , I am anxious to try again , provided I can meet with a sincere helpmeet of good family . I am the owner of the above house , rated at forty-five pounds a year , in one of the nicest streets in Putney , and I have private means of some three pounds a week , from brewery shares bringing in fifteen per cent . I will say nothing about my appearance , but enclose latest carte-de-visite photograph . ”

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I had it taken on purpose .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: “ As to my tastes , I will only say that as a general rule they are quiet . If the above seems in your line , I shall be obliged if you will write and send me particulars of yourself , with photographs .— Yours truly , JANET CANNOT . ” Well , Mrs . Cannot , your letter is an absolute model .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I suppose you did get dozens ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well —— By the way , what 's this type-written thing in the envelope ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Looking at it .It looks like a copy of your answer .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: If it is n't a rude question , Mr. Shawn , why do you typewrite your letters ? It seems so — what shall I say ?— public .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Half to himself .So thats the explanation of the typewriter .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Puzzled .I suppose it 's because you 're a private secretary .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Equally puzzled .Private secretary ! I — shall we just glance through my reply ?Reads .“ My dear Mrs . Cannot , your letter inspires me with more confidence than any of the dozens of others I have received . ”They look at each other , smiling .“ As regards myself , I should state at once that I am and have been for many years private secretary , indeed I may say almost companion , to the celebrated painter . Mr. Ilam Carve , whose magnificent pictures you are doubtless familiar with . ”

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , I 'm not .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Really . “ We have been knocking about England together for longer than I care to remember , and I personally am anxious for a change . Our present existence is very expensive . I feel the need of a home and the companionship of just such a woman as yourself . Although a bachelor , I think I am not unfitted for the domestic hearth . My age is forty . ” That 's a mistake of the typewriter .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Forty-five it ought to be .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , honestly , I should n't have thought it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: “ My age is forty-five . By a strange coincidence Mr . Carve has suggested to me that we set out for England to-morrow . At Dover I will telegraph you with a rendezvous . In great haste . Till then , my dear Mrs . Cannot , believe me , ” etc .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You did n't send a photograph .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Perhaps I was afraid of prejudicing you in advance .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Laughs .Eh , Mr. Shawn ! There 's thousands of young gentlemen alive and kicking in London this minute that would give a great deal to be only half as good looking as you are . And so you 're a bachelor ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , quite .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Two bachelors , as you say , knocking about Europe together .CARVE laughs quietly but heartily to himself .By the way , how is Mr . Carve ? I hope he 's better .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Mr . Carve ?...Suddenly stops laughing .Oh !Lamely , casually .He 's dead !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stocked .Dead ? When ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Early this morning .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Rising .And us chattering away like this . Why did n't you tell me at once , Mr. Shawn ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I forgot for the moment . I was n't thinking ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Forgot ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Simply and sincerely , but very upset .Now , Mrs . Cannot , I assure you I feel that man 's death . I admit I had very little affection for him — certainly not much respect — but we 'd been together a long time , and his death is a shock to me . Yes , really . But I 've had to think so much about my own case — and then a scene , a regular scene with Cyrus Carve . And then you coming . The fact is ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sympathetically .The fact is , you scarcely know what you 're doing , my poor Mr. Shawn . You 're on wires , that 's what 's the matter with you — hysteria . I know what it is as well as anybody . You 'll excuse me saying so , but you 're no ordinary man . You 're one of these highly-strung people and you ought to take care of yourself . Well , I 'll go now , and if it 's mutually agreeable we might perhaps meet again in a month 's time — say .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: A month ? But what am I to do with myself for a month ? Do you know you 're absolutely the only friend I 've got in London — in England . We 're never here . I 'm an utter stranger . You can n't leave me like that — for a month — four weeks — four Sundays . I have n't the least idea what 's going to happen to me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: The very best thing that can happen to you is bed . You go to bed and stop there for a couple of days . There 's nothing like it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , but where ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why , here of course .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've got to be out of this place in half an hour , less . The fact is , Cyrus Carve has been extremely — er — pert . He 's paid me a month 's salary and I 'm off at once . In under thirty minutes I shall be on the streets .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I never liked that man . Well , then , you must go to some nice respectable boarding-house .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I do n't know any nice respectable boarding-house .

lg.l: Oh ! There are thousands and thousands in London . Look in the
Telegraph .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I have n't had a paper to-day .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Any day will do . They 're in all the papers every day . What 's this ?Taking up folded dirty newspaper and opening it .Now , let 's see . Well , what about this ? “ A beautiful private hotel of the highest class . Luxuriously furnished . Visitors ’ comfort studied . Finest position in London . Cuisine a speciality . Suitable for persons of superior rank . Bathroom . Electric light . Separate tables . No irritating extras . Single rooms from two and a half guineas . 250 Queen 's Gate . ” Quite close by !CARVE says nothing .Perhaps that 's a bit dear . Here 's another . “ Not a boarding-house . A magnificent mansion . Forty bedrooms by Waring . Superb public saloons by Maple . Parisian chef . Separate tables . Four bathrooms . Card-rooms . Billiard room . Vast lounge . Special sanitation . Young , cheerful , musical society . BridgesmallFinest position in London . No irritating extras . Single rooms from two guineas . ” What about that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shakes his head .I do n't think I should fancy it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I wo n't say but what two guineas a week is a lot .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And I was thinking how cheap it was .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Staring .Well , of course , if you 've got money to fling about .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Upon my soul I do n't know what money I have got .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: It 'll be just as well to find out before you get into the street .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Let 's see . Well , there 's seven poundsshowing it .and thispulling silver and gold from another pocketNot much is it ? Sixteen shillings and sixpence . It 's true I 've an annuity of eighty pounds . I was forgetting that .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Pleased .Have you indeed ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . But an annuity is n't ready cash , is it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Picking up Shawn 's pocket-book .And this ? This seems rather thick .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I was forgetting that too .Opens it and takes out many notes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: My word ! And you 'd forgotten that ! You ought to see a doctor .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Counting .Twenty-one fives , and ten tens . That makes two hundred and five pounds .Half to himself .I always knew I was a bad lot — but where did I collar all that from ?To Janet .I know what I shall do ! I shall go to the Grand Babylon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: The Grand Babylon Hotel ? But it 's the dearest hotel in London .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: In the big towns we always went to the best hotel . It 's cheapest in the end .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You 're very persuasive , but you 'll never make me believe you 'll save money by staying at the Grand Babylon .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Rising and beginning to collect things — tries to fold up a pair of trousers .Now , Mrs . Cannot , will you do me a favour ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You 'll spoil these trousers .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Will you come and lunch with me at the Grand Babylon to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But I 've never been in such a place in my life .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Remember . You 're my only friend . Will you come and lunch with me at the Grand Babylon to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Timidly .I should like to .Suddenly .Here , give me those trousers , do !She takes hold of one leg , CARVE retaining the other .

div.stage: Enter CYRUS CARVE .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE I

stage.stage: Private sitting-room at the Grand Babylon Hotel , Strand . Luxurious in the hotel manner . Telephone . Door , L ., leading to corridor . Door , R. ( up stage ) , leading to bedroom . Another door ( not used ) leading by a passage to bathroom .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — About noon on the following day . ILAM CARVE and JANET are talking together .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'm really delighted to see you .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Examining his features .But surely you 're not feeling very well ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'm not . Perhaps it 's these sleepless nights I 've had .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You 're shivering .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I was wearing my dressing-gown . I nearly always do when I 'm alone . Do you think you 'd mind if I put it on again .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Do you mean to say you took it off because of me ?Seizing dressing-gown firmly .Mr. Shawn , will you oblige me by getting-into this at once ?She helps him on with dressing-gown .What a beauty !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . Cousin Cyrus thought so too . He did n't want me to bring it away . Still , I beat him on that point .JANET arranges the collar .Do you know , you do me good .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I should think so . I suppose when gentlemen live alone they 're pretty nearly always unwell , as it were . If it is n't a cold , it 's stomach , I expect . And truly , I 'm not surprised , the way they go on ! Now , will you sit down in that chair and keep your legs covered — August or no August ! If you ask me , it 's influenza you 're sickening for .Sound of distant orchestral .Music ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Nodding and sitting down in easy chair .Well , and what 's the news from outside ? I have n't stirred since yesterday noon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Seems to me there 's no news except your Mr . Carve 's death .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Really ! Is it so much talked about as all that ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: It 's on all the posters — very big . All along Piccadilly and Trafalgar Square and the Strand the newspaper boys , and the newspaper old men too , are wearing it like aprons , as it were . I read the Telegraph myself . There was nearly a page of it in the Telegraph .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Staggered .Nearly a page of it in the Telegraph !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , besides a leading article . Have n't you ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I never read obituaries of artists in the papers .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Neither do I . But I should have thought you would .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , they make me angry . Obituaries of archbishops are n't so bad . Newspapers seem to understand archbishops . But when they begin about artists — you cannot imagine the astounding nonsense they talk .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Protesting against his heat .Now ! You 're still all on wires . Why should that make you angry ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What did the Telegraph say ? Did you look at it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh yes . It appears Mr . Carve was a very eccentric person — avoiding society and so on .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Resentful .Eccentric ! There you are ! He was n't eccentric in the least . The only society he avoided was the society of gaping fools .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I 'm just telling you what it said . Then , let me see — what else did it say ? Oh ! It said the sole question was whether Mr . Carve was the greatest painter since Velasquez — is that how you pronounce it ?— or whether he was the greatest painter that ever lived .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Interested .Really ! It said that ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Nodding .You ought to read it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Upon my soul I think I must .Attempts to rise .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Now , please , do n't move . What is it you want ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I was only going to telephone and have the daily papers sent up .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Where is the telephone ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Pointing .There .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: So they 've put a telephone in your room ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Telephone in every room .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Going to telephone .Can I telephone for you ? I never have telephoned , and I should like to . How do you do it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Just take that thing off the hook and talk into it .JANET gingerly obeys .It wo n't explode .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What am I to say ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Tell them to send me up the daily papers at once .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: All ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But will they ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Into telephone .Please will you send up all the daily papers at once .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Thanks very much . Now you can hang it up again .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: So this is the Grand Babylon Hotel ? Well it 's a queer place .Her eyes rove round the room .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What are you looking for ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To speak plainly , I was looking for the bed . I must say I was rather surprised when the young man at the desk said I was to go up to your room .... But really , every thing 's so nicely arranged .... I suppose it 's one of those folding beds that turn into bookcases and things ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Laughs .No . This is my sitting-room .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Your sitting-room ?Pointing to door , R .Then that 's the bedroom ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Pointing to another door .And what 's that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That 's one way to my bathroom . In a big hotel I always take a suite , you know . It 's so much more comfortable .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Is n't it rather expensive ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: To tell you the truth , I did n't ask the price .

div.stage: Knock at door .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Charmingly tart .I suppose it 's what you call “ cheapest in the end . ” CARVE . Come in .

div.stage: Enter PAGE with a pile of papers .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Thanks ! Give them to me .

div.stage: Exit PAGE .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I never ! It 's like magic .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now let 's just glance at these chaps .Unfolding a paper .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Shall I help you ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why ? Here 's black borders and a heading across two columns ! “ Death of England 's greatest painter , ” “ Irreparable loss to the world 's art , ” “ Our readers will be shocked —— ” Are they all like that ?More and more astonished ; takes another paper .“ Sad death of a great genius . ”

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Handing him still another paper .And this .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: “ London 's grief . ” “ The news will come as a personal blow to every lover of great painting . ” But — but — I 'd no notion of this .Half to himself .It 's terrible .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , perhaps always living with him you would n't realize how important he was , would you ?Distant music begins again , a waltz tune .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Reading .“ Although possibly something of a poseur in his choice of subjects .... ” The fellow 's a fool . Poseur indeed !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Look at this . “ Europe in mourning . ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well — well .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What is that music ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: London 's grief . It 's the luncheon orchestra downstairs .

div.stage: Telephone bell rings .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Never mind it . Let ‘ em ring . I understand now why journalists and so on have been trying all day to see me . Honestly I 'm — I 'm staggered .

div.stage: Telephone bell continues to ring .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: It 's a funny notion of comfort having a telephone in every room . How long will it keep on like that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'll stop it .Rising .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , no .Going to telephone and taking receiver .Yes ? What 's the matter ?Listens . To CARVE .Oh , what do you think ? Father Looe and his sister , Miss Honoria Looe , want to see you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Father Looe ? Never heard of him .

lg.l: Oh , but you must have heard of him . He 's the celebrated Roman
Catholic preacher . He 's a beautiful man . I heard him preach once on the
Sins of Society .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Would you mind saying I 'm not at home ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Obviously disappointed .Then wo n't you see him ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Did you want to see him ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I should like just to have had a look at him close to , as it were .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Gallantly .Then you shall . Tell them to send him up , will you ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And am I to stay here ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , if anybody had told me this time last week ——Into telephone .Please ask them to come up .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Perhaps with your being here I sha n't be quite so shy .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Shy ! Are you shy ? It said in the Telegraph that Mr . Carve was painfully shy .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Protesting .Painfully ! Who told them that , I should like to know ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Now shyness is a thing I simply can n't understand . I 'm never shy . And you do n't strike me as shy — far from it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's very curious . I have n't felt a bit shy with you .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Nobody ever is shy with me ....Ironically .I must say I 'd give something to see you shy .

div.stage: Enter FATHER LOOE and HONORIA LOOE , announced by PAGE . ) LOOE . ( Stopping near door , at a loss . ) Pardon me — Mr. Shawn — Mr. Albert Shawn ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Rising , perturbed .Yes .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: This is your room ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: I 'm afraid there 's some mistake . I was given to understand that you were the — er — valet of the late Mr. Ilam Carve .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Yes . Mr. Cyrus Carve told us ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Coming to CARVE 'S rescue as he remains speechless , very calmly .Now there 's another trick of Mr. Cyrus Carve 's ! Valet indeed ! Mr. Shawn was Mr . Carve 's secretary — and almost companion .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Ten thousand apologies . Ten thousand apologies . I felt sure ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Please sit down .With special gallantry towards HONORIA .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And will you sit down too , Mr. Shawn ?To the LOOES .He 's not at all well . That 's why he 's wearing his dressing-gown .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Introducing .My friend , Mrs. Janet Cannot .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Now , Mr. Shawn , if you knew anything about me , if you have heard me preach , if you have read any of my books , you are probably aware that I am a man who goes straight to the point , hating subtleties . In connection with your late employer 's death a great responsibility is laid upon me , and I have come to you for information — information which I have failed to obtain either from Mr. Cyrus Carve , or the doctor , or the nurse .... Was Mr . Carve a Catholic ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: A Catholic ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: He came of a Catholic family did he not ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes — I believe so .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: The cousin , Mr. Cyrus Carve , I regret to say , denies the faith of his childhood — denies it , I also regret to say , with a vivacity that amounts almost to bad manners . In fact , he was extremely rude to me when I tried to give him some idea of the tremendous revival of Catholicism which is the outstanding feature of intellectual life in England to-day .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Ilam Carve was not a Catholic .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Mind , I do not ask if he died in the consolations of the faith . I know that he did not . I have learnt that it occurred to neither you nor the doctor nor the nurse to send for a priest . Strange omission . But not the fault of the dying man .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Ilam Carve was not a Catholic .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Then what was he ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Nothing in particular .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Then I claim him . Then I claim him .... Honoria !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: In a new tone ..Look here — what 's all this about ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Rising .I will tell you at once what it is about , Mr. Shawn . There is a question of Ilam Carve being buried in Westminster Abbey .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Thunderstruck .Buried in Westminster Abbey ?

sp.speaker: LOOK
sp.p: Lady Leonard Alcar has consulted me about the matter . I may say that I have the honour to be her spiritual director . Probably you know that Lord Leonard Alcar owns the finest collection of Ilam Carve 's pictures in Europe .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I 've often wondered who it is that settles whether people shall be buried in the Abbey or not . So it 's Lady Leonard Alcar !

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Not exactly ! Not exactly ! But Lady Leonard Alcar is a great lady . She has vast influence . The most influential convert to Catholicism of the last thirty years . She is aunt to no less than four dukes , and Lord Leonard is uncle to two others .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Ironically .I quite see .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Eagerly .You see — do n't you ? Her advice on these matters carries enormous weight . A suggestion from her amounts to — to —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: A decree absolute .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Simply .Is she what they call the ruling classes ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Bows .Lady Leonard and I have talked the matter over , and I pointed out to her that if this great genius was a member of the Church of England and if the sorrowing nation at large deems him worthy of the supreme honour of a national funeral , then by all means let him be buried in the Abbey . But if he was a Catholic , then I claim him for Westminster Cathedral , that magnificent fane which we have raised as a symbol of our renewed vitality . Now , was he a member of the Church of England ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Loudly .Decidedly not .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Good ! Then I claim him . I detest casuistry and I claim him . I have only one other question . You knew him well — intimately — for many years . On your conscience , Mr. Shawn , what interment in your opinion would he himself have preferred ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: After a pause .It would n't make much difference to him either way , would it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With an outburst .The whole thing is preposterous .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Ignoring the outburst .My course seems quite clear . I shall advise Lady Leonard —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Do n't you think you 're rather young to be in sole charge of this country ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Smoothly .My dear sir , I am nothing but a humble priest who gives counsel when counsel is sought . And I may say that in this affair of the interment of our great national painter , there are other influences than mine . For instance , my sister , Honoria , who happens also to be president of the Ladies ’ Water Colour Society —gesture of alarm from CARVE— my sister has a great responsibility . She is the favourite niece of —Whispers in CARVE 'S ear .Consequently —Makes an impressive pause .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: You see my uncle is a bachelor and I keep house for him . Anselm used to live with us too , until he left the Church .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Until I joined the Church , Honoria . Now Honoria wishes to be perfectly fair ; she entirely realizes her responsibility ; and that is why she has come with me to see you .

lg.l: So that 's how these things are decided ! I see
I 'd got quite a wrong notion of politics and so on .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Shawn — } and }Together .JANET . My idea was — }

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: I beg yours .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Granted .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: There 's one question I should so like to ask you , Mr. Shawn . In watercolours did Mr . Carve use Chinese white freely or did he stick to transparent colour , like the old English school ? I wonder if you understand me ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Interested .He used Chinese white like anything .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Oh ! I 'm so glad . You remember that charming water-colour of the Venetian gondolier in the Luxembourg . We had a great argument after we got home last Easter as to whether the oar was put in with Chinese white — or just ‘ left out , ’ you know !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Chinese white , of course . My notion is that it does n't matter a fig how you get effects so long as you do get them .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: And that was his notion too ?Telephone bell rings , JANET answers it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: His ? Rather . You bet it was .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: I 'm so glad . I 'm so glad . I knew I was right about Chinese white . Oh , Anselm , do let him be buried in the Abbey ! Do let me suggest to uncle ——

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: My dear girl , ask your conscience . Enthusiasm for art I can comprehend ; I can even sympathize with it . But if this grave national question is to be decided by considerations of Chinese white ——

div.stage: CARVE turns to JANET as if for succour .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Calmly .The doctor is just coming up .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The doctor ? What doctor ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: A Dr. Horning . He says he 's Dr. Pascoe 's assistant and he attended Mr . Carve , and he wants to see you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I do n't want to see him .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You 'll have to see a doctor .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Because you 're ill . So you may just as well see this one as another . They 're all pretty much of a muchness .

div.stage: Enter PETER HORNING boisterously . A PAGE BOY opens the door but does not announce him .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Perceiving LOOE first .Ah , Father ! You here ? How d'ye do ? What did you think of my special on last Sunday 's sermon ?Shakes hands with LOOE and bows to MISS LOOE as to an acquaintance .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Very good . Very good .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Advancing to CARVE .Mr. Shawn , I presume ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Glancing helplessly at JANET .But this is n't the doctor ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Volubly .Admitted ! Admitted ! I 'm only his brother — a journalist . I 'm on the Courier and the Mercury and several other Worgan papers . One of our chaps failed to get into this room this morning , so I came along to try what I could do . You see what I 've done .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I never came across such a set of people in my life .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Aside to LOOE .Is he in service here , or what ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Mr. Shawn was Mr . Carve 's secretary and companion , not his valet .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Puzzled , but accepting the situation .Ah ! So much the better . Now , Mr. Shawn , can you tell me authoritatively whether shortly before his death Mr . Carve was engaged to be married under romantic circumstances to a lady of high rank ?

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Indeed !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Who told you that ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Then he was !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've nothing to say .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You wo n't tell me her name ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've nothing to say .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Secondly , I 'm instructed to offer something considerable for your signature to an account of Ilam Carve 's eccentric life on the Continent .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Eccentric life on the Continent !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I should n't keep you half an hour — three quarters at most . A hundred pounds . Cash down , you know . Bank notes . All you have to do is to sign .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: To Janet , exhausted , but disdainful .I would n't mind signing an order for the fellow 's execution .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A hundred and fifty !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Or burning at the stake .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: To LOOE .What does he say ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Mr. Shawn is indisposed . We 've just been discussing the question of the burial in the Abbey . I think I may say , if it interests you as an item of news , that Ilam Carve will not be buried in the Abbey .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Lightly .Oh yes he will , Father . There was a little doubt about it until we got particulars of his will this morning . But his will settled it .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: His will ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes . Did n't you know ? No , you would n't . Well , his estate will come out at about a couple of hundred thousand , and he 's left it practically all for an International Gallery of Modern Art in London . Very ingenious plan . None of your Chantrey Bequest business . Three pictures and one piece of sculpture are to be bought each year in London . Fixed price £ 400 each , large or small . Trustees are to be business men — bank directors . But they can n't choose the works . The works are to be chosen by the students at South Kensington and the Academy Schools . Works by R. A .' s and A. R. A . ' s are absolutely barred . Works by students themselves absolutely barred , too . Cute that , eh ? That 's the arrangement for England . Similar arrangement for France , Italy , and Germany . He gives the thing a start by making it a present of his own collection — stored somewhere in Paris . I do n't mean his own paintings — he bars those . Unusually modest , eh ?

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: How perfectly splendid ! We shall have a real live gallery at last . Surely Anselm , after that —

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Quite beside the point . I shall certainly oppose .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oppose what ?

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: The burial in the Abbey . I shall advise Lady Leonard Alcar —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No use , Father . Take my word . The governor 's made up his mind . He 's been fearfully keen on art lately . I do n't know why . We were in front of everybody else with the news of Ilam Carve 's death , and the governor 's making a regular pet of him . He says it 's quite time we buried an artist in Westminster Abbey , and he 's given instructions to the whole team . Did n't you see the Mercury this morning ? Anybody who opposes a national funeral for Ilam Carve will be up against the governor . Of course , I tell you that as a friend — confidentially .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Shaken .Well , I shall see what Lady Leonard says .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Rising in an angry , scornful outburst .You 'd bury him in Westminster Abbey because he 's a philanthropist , not because he 's an artist . That 's England all over .... Well , I 'm hanged if I 'll have it .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: But , my dear sir ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And I tell you another thing — he 's not dead .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Not dead — what next ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I am Ilam Carve .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Soothingly .Poor dear ! He 's not himself .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That 's just what I am .Sinks back exhausted .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Aside to LOOE .Is he mad , Father ? Nothing but a clerk after all . And yet he takes a private room at the Grand Babylon , and then he refuses a hundred and fifty of the best and goes on like this . And now , blessed if he is n't Ilam Carve !Laughs .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: I really think we ought to leave .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: To JANET .He 's a little unhinged ! But how charming he is .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Prudently resenting HONORIA 'S interest in CARVE .Yes , he 's a little unhinged . And who would n't be ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Got ‘ em — if you ask me !Moving to leave .

sp.speaker: LOOE
sp.p: Moving to leave .Honoria .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Very soothingly and humouringly to CARVE .So this is what you call being shy !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: To JANET , who is now bending over him .It must be stopped .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: As the others go out ; humouring him .Yes , yes !Absently in reply to bows and adieux of LOOE , HONORIA , and PETER HORNING .Good morning !When they are gone , with a sigh of relief .Well , it is a mighty queer place ! My word , how cold your hands are !Going quickly to telephone and speaking into telephone .Please send up two hot-water bottles at once . Yes , hot-water bottles . Never heard of a hot-water bottle before ? The Stage is darkened for a few moments to indicate the passage of time .

div.head: SCENE 2

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — Afternoon , four days later . JANET is dozing in an easy-chair . Enter CARVE in his dressing-gown .

sp.speaker: JANET
