sp.p: Starting up .Mr. Shawn , what are you doing out of bed ? After such a dose of flu as you 've had !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'm doing nothing out of bed .Twiddles his thumbs .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But you 've no right to be out of bed at all .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I was afraid I had n't . But I called and called , and there was no answer . So then I began to argue the point . Why not get up ? I 'd had a tremendous long sleep . I felt singularly powerful . And I thought you 'd gone home .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Nay — that you never did !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I did , honestly .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Do you mean to say you thought for a single moment I should go home and leave you like that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes . But of course I thought you might be coming back sooner or later .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well I never !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 've scarcely left me for three days and three nights , Mrs . Cannot , so far as I remember . Surely it was natural for me to suppose that you 'd gone home to your own affairs .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sarcastically .It did n't occur to you I might have dropped off to sleep ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now , do n't be angry . I 'm only convalescent .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Will you kindly march right back to bed this instant ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , I 'm dashed if I do !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I beg pardon .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I say , I 'm dashed if I do ! I wo n't stir until I 've thanked you . I 've been ill I do n't know how many times ; but this is the first time in my life I 've ever enjoyed being ill. D'you knowwith an ingenuous smile .I 'd really no idea what nursing was .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Drily .Had n't you ? Well , if you call that nursing , I do n't . But it was the best I could do in this barracks , with the kitchen a mile and a half off , and a pack of men that can n't understand English gaping at you all day in evening-dress . I dare say this is a very good hotel for reading newspapers in . But if you want anything that is n't on the menu , it 's as bad as drawing money out of the post office savings bank . You should see me nurse in my own house .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I should like to . Even in this barracksimitating her .you 've quite altered my views of life .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , and they wanted altering . When I think of you and that other poor fellow wandering about all alone on that Continent — without the slightest notion of what comfort is .... Well , I 'll say this — it 's a pleasure to nurse you . Now , will you go back to bed ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I suppose coffee 's on the menu ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Coffee ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I think I should like some café au lait , and a roll .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Rising .You can have hot milk if you like .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: All right . And then when I 've had it I 'll go to bed .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: At telephone .Are you there ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Picking up a sheet of paper from table .Hello ! What 's this ? Hotel bill-receipted ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I should think so indeed ! They sent it up the second day .Into telephone .Hot milk , please , and let it be hot !Hanging up telephone . To CARVE .I expect they were afraid for their money .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And you paid it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I took the money out of your pockets and I just paid it . I never said a word . But if you had n't been ill I should have said something . Of all the swindles , of all the barefaced swindles !... Do you see what it 's costing you to live here — a day ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , not much above four pounds , I hope .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Speechless at first .Any woman that knew her business could keep you for a month — a month — for less than you spend here in a day — and better . And better ! Look here : “ Biscuits , 1s . 6d .! ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Wellconfidentially earnest ., will you believe me when I tell you there was n't a pennyworth of biscuits on that plate ? Do you think I do n't know what biscuits are a pound ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Ironically .“ Cheapest in the end ” — but I should say the end 's a long way off .

lg.stage: Who has picked up another paper , on mantelpiece .
lg.l: What ? “ Admit
Mr. Albert Shawn to Westminster Abbey , cloisters entrance ....
Funeral .... Tuesday . ” ... That 's to-day , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes .

lg.l: But you told me he was n't going to be buried in
Westminster Abbey .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You told me Cyrus Carve had insisted on cremation .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: With vivacity .And what did you expect me to tell you ? I had to soothe you somehow ; you were just about delirious . I was afraid if I told you the truth you 'd be doing something silly — seeing the state you were in . Then it struck me a nice plain cremation at Woking was the very thing to keep you quiet .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Still more moved .Then he 's .... Westminster Abbey !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , I should say all is over by this time . There were thousands of people for the lying-in-state , it seems .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But it 's awful . Absolutely awful .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why is it awful ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I told you — I explained the whole thing to you .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Humouring , remonstrating .Mr. Shawn , surely you 've got rid of that idea ! You are n't delirious now . You said you were convalescent , you know .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: There 'll be a perfect Hades of a row . I must write to the Dean at once . I must ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Soothingly .I should n't if I were you . Why not let things be ? No one would believe that tale ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Do you believe it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Perfunctorily .Oh yes .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , you do n't . Honestly , do you now ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well ——Knock at door .Come in .Enter WAITER with hot milk .Here 's your hot milk .

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: Miss Looe has called .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I must see her .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I must see her .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , very well .Exit WAITER .She 's telephoned each day to inquire how you were . She asked if you wanted a seat for the funeral . I told her you could n't possibly go , but I was sure you 'd like to be invited — whether it was the Abbey or not . Please do n't forget your milk .

div.stage: Enter HONORIA LOOE in mourning , introduced by WAITER .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Coming in quickly , bowing to JANET and shaking hands with CARVE .Good afternoon . Please do n't rise . I 've heard how ill you 've been . I 've only called because I simply had to .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's very kind of you .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Shawn , I know you did n't want him to be buried in the Abbey . I 'm all for quiet funerals , too ; but really this was an exceptional case , and I think if you 'd seen it you 'd have been glad they did decide on the Abbey . Oh , you 've no idea how impressive it was ! The Abbey is always so fine , is n't it ? And it was crammed . You never saw such a multitude of distinguished people . I mean really distinguished — all in black , except , of course , the uniforms . Royalties , ambassadors , representatives from all the academies all over Europe . Rodin was there !! The whole of artistic London came . I do n't mean only painters , but poets , novelists , sculptors , and musicians . The art students had a corner to themselves . And you should have seen the crowds outside . All traffic was stopped up as far as Trafalgar Square . I 've had some difficulty in getting here . The sun was shining through the stained glass . And the music was magnificent . And then when the coffin was carried down the nave — well , there was only one wreath on the pall — just one — a white crown . All the other wreaths were piled near the screen — scores and scores of them — the effect was tremendous . I nearly cried . A lot of people did cry .Genuinely moved .There was that great genius lying there . He 'd never done anything except put paint on canvas , and yet — and yet .... Well , it made you feel somehow that England does care for art after all .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After a pause .And whom have we to thank for this beautiful national manifestation of sympathy with art ?

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: How do you mean ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With an attempt at cold irony , but yet in a voice imperfectly controlled .Did your brother relent and graciously permit Lady Leonard Alcar to encourage a national funeral ? Or was it due solely to the influence of the newspapers written by people of refined culture like the man who gave his opinion the other day that I had got ‘ em ? Or perhaps you yourself settled it with your esteemed uncle over a cup of tea ?

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Of course , Mr. Shawn , any one can see that you 're artistic yourself , and artists are generally very sarcastic about the British public . I know I am .... Now , do n't you paint ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .I used to — a little .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: I was sure of it . Well , you can be as sarcastic as you like , but do you know what I was thinking during the service ? I was thinking if only he could have seen it — if only Ilam Carve could have seen it — instead of lying cold in that coffin under that wreath , he 'd —Hesitating .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Interrupting her , in a different , resolved tone .Miss Looe , I suppose you 're on very confidential terms with your uncle .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Naturally . Why ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Will you give him a message from me . He 'll do perhaps better than anybody .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: With pleasure .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Moved .It is something important — very important indeed . In fact —

div.stage: JANET goes into bedroom , but keeping near the doorway does not actually disappear .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Soothingly , and a little frightened .Now , please , Mr. Shawn ! Please do n't frighten us as you did the other day . Please do try and keep calm !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I —He suddenly stands up and then falls back again into chair .

div.stage: JANET returns quickly to the room

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Alarmed , to JANET .I 'm afraid he is n't quite well yet .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , I can n't tell you . At least , not now . Thanks very much for calling .Rises brusquely and walks towards the bedroom door .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To HONORIA .He 's not really strong enough to see visitors .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Going to door and trying to be confidential .What is it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: With tranquillity .Oh , influenza . Sometimes it takes ‘ em in the head and sometimes in the stomach . It 's taken him in the head .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Charming man ! I do n't suppose there 's the least likelihood of it — he 's evidently very well off — but if he should be wanting a situation similar to his last , I 'm sure my uncle ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Positively and curtly .I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: Of course you know him very well ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , it 's like this . I 'm his cousin . We are n't exactly engaged to be married ——

sp.speaker: HONORIA
sp.p: In a changed tone .Oh , I see ! Good afternoon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Good afternoon .

div.stage: Exit HONORIA .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Who has hesitatingly wandered back towards centre ; in a quite different tone now that he is alone again with JANET .What 's this about being engaged to be married ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Smiling .I was telling her we were n't engaged to be married . That 's true , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But are we cousins ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes . I 've got my reputation to think about . I do n't want to coddle it , but there 's no harm in just keeping an eye on it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I see .Sits down .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: If nothing comes of all this —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: All what ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: All this illness and nursing and sitting up at nights ,— then I 'm just your cousin , and no harm done .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But do you mean to say you 'd —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stopping-him .Not so fast !Pause . She continues reflectively .Do you know what struck me while her ladyship was telling you about all the grand doings at the funeral — What good has it ever done him to be celebrated and make a big splash in the world ? Was he any happier for it ? From all I can hear he was always trying to hide just as if the police were after him . He never had the slightest notion of comfort , and so you need n't tell me ! And there 's another thing — you need n't tell me he was n't always worrying about some girl or other , because I know he was . A bachelor at his age never thinks about anything else — morning , noon , and night . It stands to reason — and they can say what they like — I know . And now he 's dead — probably because he 'd no notion of looking after himself , and it 's been in all the papers how wonderful he was , and florists ’ girls have very likely sat up half the night making wreaths , and Westminster Abbey was crowded out with fashionable folk — and do you know what all those fashionable folk are thinking about just now — tea ! And if it is n't tea , it 's whisky and soda .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But you must n't forget that he was really very successful indeed .... Just look at the money he made , for instance .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , if sovereigns had been any use to him he 'd never have left two hundred thousand of them behind him — him with no family . No , he was no better than a fool with money . Could n't even spend it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: He had the supreme satisfaction of doing what he enjoyed doing better than anybody else could do it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And what was that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Painting .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Casually .Oh ! and could n't he have had that without running about all over Europe ? He might just as well have been a commercial traveller . Take my word for it , Mr. Shawn , there 's nothing like a comfortable home and a quiet life — and the less you 're in the newspapers the better .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Thoughtfully .Do you know — a good deal of what you say applies to me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And you now ! As we 're on the subject — before we go any further — you 're a bachelor of forty-five , same as him . What have you been doing with yourself lately ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Doing with myself ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I think I ought to ask because when I was stealingwith a little nervous laughthe money out of your pocket to pay that hotel bill , I came across a lady 's photograph . I could n't help coming across it . Seeing how things are , I think I ought to ask .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , that ! It must be a photograph of the lady he was engaged to . He broke it off , you know . That was why we came to London in such a hurry .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Then it is true — what the newspaper reporter said ?CARVE nods .One of the aristocracy —CARVE nods .Who was she ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lady Alice Rowfant .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What was it doing in your pocket ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I do n't know . Everything got mixed up . Clothes , papers , everything .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sure ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Of course ! Look here , do you suppose Lady Alice Rowfant is anything to me ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: She is n't ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Honestly ?Looking at him closely .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Honestly .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: With obvious relief .Well , that 's all right then ! Now will you drink this milk , please .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I just wanted to tell you ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Will you drink this milk ?Pours out a glassful for him .

div.stage: CARVE addresses himself to the milk .
JANET begins to put on her things .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I say , what are you doing ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I 'm going home .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What ? Now ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: At once .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But you can n't leave me like this . I 'm very ill .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh no , you are n't . You 're very much better . Anyone can see that . All you 've got to do is to return to bed and stick to slops .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And when shall you come back ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You might come down to see me one day at Putney .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I shall be delighted to . But before that , wo n't you come here ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: After a pause .I 'll try and come the day after to-morrow .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why not to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , a couple of days without me 'll do you no harm . It 's a mistake to be in a hurry when you 've got all your life in front of you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After a pause .Listen — have some tea before you go .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No .Holds out her hand , smiling .Good afternoon . Now do go to bed .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I have n't begun to thank you .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No — and I hope you wo n't begin .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 're so sudden .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: It 's sudden or nothing .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Holding her hand .I say — what can you see in me ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , if it comes to that — what can you see in me ?Withdrawing her hand .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I — I do n't know what it is .... Something ....Lightly .I dunno ! Everything !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: That 's too much . Good-bye ! I 'll come about this time the day after to-morrow .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Supposing I have a relapse ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: At door .You wo n't if you do as I tell you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But supposing I do ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , you can always telegraph , can n't you ?

div.stage: Exit .
CARVE , after finishing milk , suddenly gets up and searches on writing table : he then goes to the telephone .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Into telephone .Please send me up a telegraph form .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE I

stage.stage: Parlour in Janet 's house in Putney . A perfectly ordinary suburban interior of a small house ; but comfortable . Table in centre . Door , R ., up stage , leading to hall . Door , L ., down stage , hading to kitchen and back premises .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — Morning in early autumn . Rather more than two years have elapsed . Discovered — CARVE reading newspaper at breakfast-table . JANET in an apron is hovering busily near him .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Putting cigarettes and matches down beside CARVE .Want anything else , dear ?No answer from CARVE .Because I must set about my morning 's work .CARVE continues to read .Albert , are you sure you do n't want anything else ?

div.stage: As he still gives her no sign of attention , she snatches the paper away from him , and throws it on the floor .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Not having moved his eyes .The pattern of this jug is really not so bad .... Yes , my soul ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I 've asked you I do n't know how many times whether you want anything else , because I must set about my morning 's work .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Is there any more coffee ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , plenty .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Hot ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Then I do n't want any . Got any bacon ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , but I can cook a slice in a minute .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With an affectation of martyrdom .Does n't matter .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh yes , I will .Moving away .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Drawing her to him by her apron .Ca n't you see he 's teasing you ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: She 's got no time in the morning for being teased .

div.stage: She takes a cigarette , lights it and immediately puts it in his mouth .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And now you 're going to leave me ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sure you 're all right ?He nods .Quite sure you 're happy ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jane —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I wish you would n't call me Jane .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I will call you Jane . Jane , why do you ask me if I 'm sure I 'm happy ? When a man has first-class food and first-class love , together with a genuine French bed , really waterproof boots , a constant supply of hot water in the bathroom , enough money to buy cigarettes and sixpenny editions , the freedom to do what he likes all day and every day — and — let me see , what else — a complete absence of domestic servants — then either that man is happy or he is a silly cuckoo !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You are n't getting tired —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: My sweet child , what 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Nothing , nothing . Only to-day 's the second anniversary of our wedding — and you 've — you 've said nothing about it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After a shocked paused .And I forgot it last year , did n't I ? I shall be forgetting my dinner next .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh no , you wo n't !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And yet all last week I was thinking about this most important day , and telling myself I must remember it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Very easy to say that . But how can you prove it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , it does just happen that the proof is behind the sideboard .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: A present ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: A present . It was all ready and waiting five days ago .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Drawing a framed picture from behind the sideboard , and trying to hide her disappointment , but not quite succeeding .Oh ! A picture ! Who is it ?Examines it with her nose close to it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No , no . You can n't take a picture like snuff ! Get away from it .He jumps up , snatches the picture from her , and exposes it on a chair at the other side of the room .Now !He sits down again .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , it does n't look quite so queer like that . Those are my cooking sleeves , and that seems a bit like my kitchen — that 's my best copper pan ! Is the young woman meant to be me ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , not to beat about the bush , yes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I do n't consider it very flattering .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: How many times have you told me you hate flattery ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Running to him .Now he 's hurt . Oh , he 's hurt .Kissing him .It 's a beautiful picture , and the frame 's lovely ! And she 's so glad he did n't forget .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It is pretty good . In fact it 's devilish good . It 's one of the best things I ever did in my life . Old Carve would have got eight hundred for that like a shot .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sceptically .Would he ? It 's wonderful how wonderful people are when they 're dead .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And now will she let him finish reading his paper ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Handing him the paper , then putting her head close to his and looking at the paper .What was it he was reading that made him so deaf he could n't hear his wife when she spoke to him ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: This .

lg.l: “ Ilam Carve 's princely bequest . The International
Gallery of Art . Foundation stone laying . Eloquent speech by Lord
Rosebery . ” Oh ! So they 've begun it at last ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , they 've begun it at last .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , if you ask me , I should have thought he could have found something better to do with his money .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: As for example ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I should have thought there were more than enough picture galleries as it is . Who wants ‘ em ? Even when they 're free , people wo n't go into them unless it 's a wet day . I 've never been in a free picture gallery yet that was n't as empty as a church . Stands to reason ! It is n't even a cinematograph . When I see rows of people in Trafalgar Square waiting to get into the National Gallery , then I shall begin to think it 's about time we had some more galleries . If I 'd been Ilam Carve ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , what should you have done , witch ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I should have left a bit more to you , for one thing .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I do n't want more . If he 'd left me eight hundred a year instead of eighty , I should n't be any happier . That 's just what I 've learnt since I took lodgings in your delightful wigwam , Jane — money and fame have no connection whatever with happiness .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Money has , when you have n't got enough .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I have . You wo n't hear of me paying more than half the household expenses , and you say they 're never more than thirty shillings a week . Half thirty — fifteen . Look at the balance it leaves me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And supposing I had to ask you to pay more ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: In a serious sympathetic tone , startled .Anything wrong ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , there 's nothing wrong , as it were — yet ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jane , I do believe you 've been hiding something from me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: With difficulty pulls a letter from her pocket .No —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 've felt it for several days .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You just have n't then . Because I only got it this morning . Here , you may as well read it .Handing him the letter .It 's about the brewery .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Reading .“ Mrs. Albert Shawn . Sir or Madam . ” — Why are shareholders never supposed to have any particular sex ?— “ Sir or Madam . Cohoon 's Brewery , Ltd .,— I am directed by the shareholders ’ provisional committee of investigation to request your attendance at an informal meeting of shareholders to be held in room 2009 Winchester House on Friday the 20th inst . at noon . If you cannot be present , will you kindly write stating whether or not you will be prepared to support the committee of investigation at the annual meeting . In view of the probability that the directors ’ report will be unfavourable , and the ordinary dividend either passed or much reduced , the committee wishes to be thoroughly prepared and armed . Believe me , Sir or Madam . ” Oh ! So that 's it , is it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes . My father said to me before he died , “ Keep the money in beer , Janet ” ; he said , “ Beer 'll never fail in this country . ” And there you are !

div.stage: She goes to fireplace , opens coal scuttle , takes out a piece of paper ready placed within , and sticks it on the handle so as to keep her hands from being soiled as she replenishes the fire .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lightly .Oh , well ! We must wait and see what happens .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Supposing the dividend does n't happen ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I never worry about money .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But we shall want to eat once or twice pretty nearly every day , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Personally , I am quite satisfied with a plain but perfect table .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You need n't tell me what you are satisfied with . You 're satisfied with the very best at one shilling and sixpence a pound .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I can place eighty pounds per annum at your absolute disposal . That alone will pay for over a thousand best cuts .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , and what about your clothes and my clothes , and the rates and taxes , and bus-fares , and holidays , and your cigarettes , and doctor , and errand boys ’ Christmas-boxes , and gas , and coal , and repairs ? Repairs ! A hundred and eighty is more like what we want .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And yet you have several times taken your Bible oath that my half-share of it all came to less than forty pounds .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well — er — I was thinking of food .She begins to collect the breakfast things .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jane , you have been a deceitful thing . But never mind . I will draw a veil over this sinful past . Let us assume that beer goes all to pieces , and that you never get another cent out of Cohoon 's . Well , as you need a hundred and eighty a year , I will give you a hundred and eighty a year .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And where shall you get the extra hundred ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I shall earn it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , you do n't . I wo n't have you taking any more situations .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I shall earn it here .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Painting !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stopping her work and coming towards him , half-caressing and half-chiding .I do n't mind this painting business . Do n't think I object to it in the least . There 's a strong smell with it now and then , but it does keep you quiet in the attic while I 'm cleaning the house , and that 's something . And then going out making sketches you get exercise and fresh air . Being with Ilam Carve so long , I expect you picked up the habit as it were , and I 'm sure I do n't want you to drop it . I love to see you enjoying yourself . But you do n't suppose people 'll buy these thingspointing vaguely to picture on chair, do you ? No ; there 's far too many amateur artists about for that !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: If I wanted , I could take a cab and sell that in Bond Street inside sixty minutes at my own price . Only I do n't want .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Now , just listen to me . You remember that picture you did of Putney Bridge with the saloon entrance of the Reindeer Public House showing in the corner ? It was one of the first you did here .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , I was looking for it the other day , and I could n't find it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I 'm not surprised . Because it 's sold .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Sold ?Excited .What in the name of ——

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Soothing him .Now — now ! Do you remember you said Ilam Carve would have got £ 1000 for a thing just like that ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: So he would . It was absolutely characteristic .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I said to myself , “ He seems mighty sure of himself . Supposing it 's me that 's wrong ? ” So one day I quietly took that picture round to Bostock 's , the second-hand furniture man , you know ,— he was a friend of father 's ,— and I asked him what he 'd give me for it . He would n't take it at any price . Not at any price . Then I asked him if he 'd keep it in his shop and sell it for me on commission . Well , it stuck in Bostock 's shop — in his window and out of his window — for twelve months and more , and then one day the landlord of the Reindeer saw it and he bought it for six shillings , because his public-house was in it . He was half-drunk . Mr. Bostock charged me eighteenpence commission , and I bought you two neckties with the four and six , and I said nothing because I did n't want your feelings to be hurt . And that reminds me , last week but one they took the landlord of the Reindeer off to the lunatic asylum .... So , you see !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Serious , preoccupied .And where 's the picture now ?

lg.l: I should n't be surprised if it 's in the private bar of the
Reindeer .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I must get hold of it .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Albert , you are n't vexed , are you ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Forcing himself to adopt a light tone .How could I be vexed with two neckties to the good ? But do n't do it again , Jane . I shall go round to the Reindeer this morning and have a drink . If that picture ever found its way to a Bond Street expert 's , the consequences might be awkward — devilish awkward . Because it 's dated , you see .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , I do n't see . I should n't have said a word about it , only I wanted to save you from being disappointed later on .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: In a new casual tone .Just get me my cash-box , will you ?

div.stage: JANET at once produces the cash-box from a drawer .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And what now ? I 'm not broke yet , you great silly .Laughs , but is rather intimidated by CARVE 'S air .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Having unlocked box and taken a bag from it .You see that ?He showers gold out of it .Well , count it !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Gracious ! Ten — fifteen — eighteen — twenty ?— two — four — twenty-six pounds . These your savings ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: That 's what I 've earned with painting , just at odd times .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Really ?CARVE nods .You could knock me down with a feather !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'll tell you . You know the framemaker 's next to Salmon and Gluckstein 's . I buy my colours and canvases and things there . They cost money . I owed the chap two pounds once , and one morning , in the shop , when I was opening my box to put some new tubes in , he saw one of my pictures all wet . He offered of his own accord to take it for what I owed him . I would n't let him have it . But I was rather hard up , so I said I 'd do him another instead , and I did him one in a different style and not half as good , and of course he liked it even better . Since then , I 've done him quite a few . It is n't that I 've needed the money ; but it 's a margin , and colours and frames , etc . come to a dickens of a lot in a year .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Staggered .And whatever does he do with them ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With the pictures ? Do n't know . I 've never seen one in his window . I have n't been selling him any lately .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , I did n't feel like it . And the things were getting too good . But , of course , I can start again any time .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Still staggered .Two pounds a piece ?CARVE nods .Would he give you two pounds for that ?Pointing to portrait .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You bet he would .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why ! Two pounds would keep us for the best part of a week . How long does it take you to do one ?

div.stage: Noise of motor car outside .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , three or four hours . I work pretty quickly .

lg.l: Well , it 's like a fairy tale . Two pounds ! I do n't know whether
I 'm standing on my head or my heels !

div.stage: Violent ringing at front door bell .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: There 's one of your tradesmen .

lg.l: It is n't . They know better than come to my front door . They know
I wo n't have it .

div.stage: Exit , throwing off apron .
CARVE examines the portrait of his wife with evident pleasure .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: To himself .That ‘ ud make ‘ em sit up in Bond Street .Laughs grimly .

div.stage: Voices off . Re-enter JANET , followed by EBAG carrying a picture .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , it never rains but it pours . Here 's a gentleman in a motor car wants to know if you 've got any pictures for sale .She calmly conceals her apron .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: With diplomatic caution and much deference .Good-morning .

lg.stage: Whose entire demeanour has suddenly changed into hostility .
lg.l: Good-morning .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I 've been buying some very delightful little things of yours from a man that calls himself a picture-dealer and frame-makerironicallyin the High Street here . I persuaded him — not without difficulty — to give me your address . And I 've ventured to call just to see if by chance you have anything for sale .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: By chance I have n't !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Nothing at all ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Not a square inch .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Catching sight of Janet 's portrait .Pardon me . May I look ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , do !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: A brilliant likeness .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Who of ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Why , madam — yourself ? The attitude is extraordinarily expressive . And if I may say soglancing at CARVEthe placing of the high lights — those white sleevelets — what d'you call them ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why ! Those are my cooking-sleeves !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Quietly .Yes — well — it 's genius — mere genius .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Looking at picture afreshIt is rather pretty when you come to look at it .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: It is a masterpiece , madam .To CARVE .Then I may not make an offer for it ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Excuse me , Albert . Why should n't the gentleman make an offer for it ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Quickly seizing an opportunityIf you cared to consider , say , five hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Five hundred p ——

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I came down quite prepared to spend — and to pay cash .Fingers his pocket-book .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sitting down .And if it is n't a rude question — do you generally go about with five hundred pounds in your pocket , as it were ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Raising his hands .In my business , madam —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's not for sale .Turns it round .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Vivaciously .Oh yes , it is . Somebody in this house must think about the future .Cajolingly .If this gentleman can show me five hundred pounds it 's for sale . After all , it 's my picture . And you can do me another one . I 'd much sooner be done without the cooking-sleeves .Entreating .Albert !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Shy , nervous , and tongue-tied .Well !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Endearingly .That 's right ! That 's all right !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Putting down notes .If you will kindly count these —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Taking the notes .Nay , I 'm too dizzy to count them .As if giving up any attempt to realize the situation .It fairly beats me ! I never did understand this art business , and I never shall ....To EBAG .Why are you so interested in my portrait ? You 've never seen me before .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Madam , your portrait happens to be one of the very finest modern paintings I ever saw .To CARVE .I have a picture here as to which I should like to ask your opinion .Exposing picture .I bought it ten years ago .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After seeing picture .Janet , would you mind leaving us a minute .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Triumphant with her money .Not a bit .

div.stage: Exit , L .

lg.stage: Bowing to JANET . Then to CARVE .
lg.l: It 's signed “ Ilam Carve . ”
Should you say it 's a genuine Carve ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: More and more disturbed .Yes .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Where was it painted ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why do you ask me ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Quietly dramatic .Because you painted it .Pause . He approaches CARVE .Master ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Master !

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Impulsively .Look here ! I never could stick being called “ master ” ! It 's worse even than “ maître . ” Have a cigarette ? How did you find out who I was ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Pointing to Janet 's portrait .Is n't that proof enough ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , but you knew before you saw that .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: After lighting-cigarette .I did . I knew from the very first picture I bought from our friend the “ picture-dealer and frame-maker ” in the early part of last year .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I 'd completely altered my style . I altered it on purpose .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Shaking his head .My dear sir , there was once a well-known man who stood six feet ten inches high . He shaved off his beard and dyed his hair , and invented a very ingenious costume , and went to a Fancy Dress Ball as Tom Thumb . Strange to say , his disguise was penetrated immediately .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Who are you ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: My name is Ebag — New Bond Street .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What ! You 're my old dealer !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: And I 'm delighted at last to make your acquaintance , sir . It was n't until I 'd bought several of those small canvases from the Putney man that I began to inquire closely into their origin . As a general rule it 's a mistake for a dealer to be too curious . But my curiosity got the better of me . And when I found out that the pictures were being produced week by week , fresh , then I knew I was on the edge of some mystery .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Awkwardly .The fact is , perhaps , I ought to explain .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Pardon me . I ask nothing . It is n't my affair . I felt certain , solely from the evidence of what I was buying , that the great painter who was supposed to be buried in Westminster Abbey , and whose somewhat premature funeral I attended , must be alive and painting vigorously . I wanted the assurance from your lips . I have it . The rest does not concern me — at any rate , for the moment .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I 'll say this — you know a picture when you see it .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Proudly .I am an expert , nothing else .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: All right ! Well , I 'll only ask you to persevere in your discretion . As you say , it is n't your affair . Thank goodness , I did n't put a date on any of these things . I wo n't sell any more . I 'd take an oath never to paint again , only I know I should go and break it next week . I shall rely on this famous discretion of yours to say nothing — nothing whatever .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I 'm afraid it 's too late .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: How too late ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I 'm afraid I shall have to ask you to state publicly that you are Ilam Carve , and that there must have been — er — some misapprehension , somewhere , over that funeral .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Aghast .Publicly ? Why ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: It 's like this , I 've been selling those pictures to Texel in New York . You remember , he 's always been one of your principal collectors . He 's getting old , and he 's half-blind , but he still buys . Now , I rely on my judgment , and I guaranteed those pictures to be genuine Carves . Well , somebody over there must have had suspicions .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What does that matter ? There is n't a date on any of them .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Just so . But in one of those pictures there 's most distinctly a taxi-cab . It is n't a private motor car . It 's a taxi .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And if there is ? No law against painting a taxi , I hope !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Again quietly dramatic .No . But at the date of your funeral there was n't a single taxi on the streets of London .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The devil !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Exactly . Texel is bringing an action against me for misrepresentation . I shall have to ask you to give evidence and say who you are .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Angrily .But I wo n't give evidence ! You 've brought this on yourself . How much did you sell those little pictures for ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Oh , an average of between four and five hundred .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And what did you pay for them ? I ask you , what did you pay for them ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Smoothly .Four pounds a piece . The fact is — I did rather well out of them .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Damned Jew !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Smoothly .Damned — possibly . Jew — most decidedly . But in this particular instance I behaved just like a Christian . I paid a little less than I was asked , and sold for the highest I could get . I am perfectly innocent , and my reputation is at stake .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I do n't care .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: But I do . It 's the reputation of the greatest expert in Europe . And I shall have to insist on you going into the witness-box .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Horrified .Me in the witness-box ! Me cross-examined ! No . That 's always been my nightmare !

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Nevertheless —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Please go .Commandingly .Please go .

div.stage: EBAG , intimidated by CARVE 'S demeanour , picks up his pictures to depart .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: At door .Your wife will perhaps be good enough to post me a receipt for that trifle .Very respectfully .Good-morning .

div.stage: Exit , R .
CARVE goes to door , L ., and opens it . JANET is standing behind it .
Enter JANET .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 've been listening ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Counting her banknotes .Well , naturally !Putting notes in her purse .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Here 's a perfect Hades of a mess .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And it all comes of this painting . Art as it 's called .She finds her apron and puts it on .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: With an air of discovery .Your faculty for keeping calm really is most singular .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Somebody has to keep calm .

div.stage: Voice off : “ Butcher . ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Anybody would say you did n't care a cent whether I 'm Ilam Carve or whether I 'm somebody else .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What does it matter to me who you are , so long as you 're you ? Men are so unpractical . You can be the Shah of Persia if you like — I do n't mind .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But are n't you convinced now ?

div.stage: Voice off : “ Butcher . ”

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: With an enigmatic smile at CARVE .Coming ! Coming !

div.stage: Exit .
The stage is darkened to indicate the passage of several months .

div.head: SCENE 2

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — Before daylight on a morning in February . Fire burning in grate . Also a speck of gas . Otherwise it is dark . CARVE is discovered reposing-in an easy-chair . Enter JANET with a candle .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stiffly .So you 've not been to sleep either ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Stiffly .Oh yes ; had an excellent night in this chair .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Going to fire .Now , you 're only boasting . If you 've had such an excellent nightimitating him, who 's kept up such an excellent fire ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lamely .Well , of course I looked after it now and then . I did n't want to perish in my solitude .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Then why did n't you come to bed , great baby ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Sitting up with solemnity .Janet , we are a pair of great babies to have quarrelled like that ,— especially at bedtime .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Simply .Quarrelled ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , did n't we ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I did n't . I agreed with everything you said .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What did you agree with ? I should like to know .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You said I did n't really believe after all that you are Ilam Carve , and I assured you in the most soothing manner that I did believe you are Ilam Carve !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And do you call that agreeing with me ? I know perfectly well from your tone that in spite of all my explanations and reiterations during the last three months you do n't believe I 'm Ilam Carve . You only say you do in order to soothe me . I hate being soothed . You 're as convinced as ever that Ebag is a rascal , and that I 've got a bee in my bonnet .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: But what does it matter ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Cold and hard .Well , I like that !

lg.l: It 's not my fault if I do n't believe you 're Ilam
Carve . I would if I could , but I can n't ! You 're very cruel .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jumping up and embracing her .Hush , hush ! There !Cajolingly .Who 's being an infant now ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I do n't pretend to understand this art .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I hope you never will . One of the chief charms of existence in your wigwam , my child , is that I never hear any confounded chatter about art . Now — are we pals ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Smiling reconciliation .Darling , do turn the gas up .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Obeying , struck by her attire .Why — what are you dressed like that for ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I was thinking of going away .

div.stage: Exit , L .
She re-enters immediately with kettle and puts it on fire .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Going away ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Smiling .Now do listen , darling . Let 's go away . We can n't stop here . This Ebag case is getting more and more on your nerves , and on mine too . I 'm sure that 's what 's the matter with us . What it 'll be next week when the trial comes on , I do n't know — upon my soul I do n't . It 's all very well for you to refuse to see callers and never go out . But I can tell you one thing — we shall have those newspaper people on the roof in a day or two , and looking down the chimney to see how I lay the fire . Lawyers are nothing to them . Do you know — no you do n't , because I did n't want you to be upset — last night 's milk was brought by a journalist — with a camera . They 're beginning to bribe the tradesmen . I tremble to think what will be in this morning 's papers .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Trying to make light of it .Oh , nothing will upset me now . But you might let me know at once if the editor of the Spectator calls round with the bread .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And I 'll tell you another thing . That Mr. Horning — you know the breathless man on the Evening Courier that came to the Grand Babylon — he 's taken lodgings opposite — arrived last night .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , for a machine gun — one simple little machine gun !Exit JANET , L .She immediately returns with a tray containing bread , etc ., and a toasting-fork .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: So I thought if we just vanished —

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's too late — I 've had the subpoena . If I hooked it , everybody would say I was an adventurer .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: We could come back for the trial .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: We should be followed .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Not if we start now .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , now ! The back door . Before it gets light .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Creep away in the dark ! No ! I 'll go through with the thing .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I shall travel alone , then . Here 's my bunch of keys . I 'll just explain to you where everything is . I daresay Mrs. Simpson will come in and clean up . She 's not bad , as charwomen go .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Jane !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 're taking an unfair advantage of me .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Putting tea leaves in teapot .What if I am ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 're only a woman after all .... And I 'd thought so highly of you !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sweetly .Then you 'll come . Better brush yourself up first .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What time is it ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Looking at clock .Seven o'clock .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Where do you mean to drag me to ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , what about this Continent of yours that I 've heard so much of ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: There 's a train from Victoria at 8. 30 .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Very well then . We 'll have another breakfast at Victoria .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And the cab ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: There is n't going to be any cab — nor luggage — rousing the whole street !CARVE goes to window .For goodness ’ sake do n't draw those curtains — with the gas flaring up !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Conspiratorial .Supposing there 's some journalist on the watch outside !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I wanted to look at the weather .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , go to the front door , and mind you open it quietly .

div.stage: Exit CARVE , R .
JANET pours water on tea .
Exit , L .
Re-enter CARVE quickly .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I say , here 's a curate pushed himself in at the front door !

div.stage: Re-enter JANET , L .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , he 's come in at the back .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: But I tell you he 's here !

div.stage: Enter JAMES SHAWN , L. Then enter JOHN SHAWN , R. Pause .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Now let me entreat everybody to remain perfectly calm .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , do n't worry about that . Nothing startles us now . A few curates more or less ....

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Sinking into chair .I suppose this is the very newest journalism . Would you mind me asking a question ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: What is it ?

div.stage: JANET makes the tea .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why did you wait till the door was opened ? Seems a pity to stand on ceremony . Why not have broken a window or so and climbed right in ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: John , is mother there ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: At door , R .Mother , how often shall I have to ask you to keep close to me ?

div.stage: Enter MRS. SHAWN , R .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: I 'm all of a tremble .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Firmly .Come now , you must n't give way . This is hepointing to CARVEDo you recognise him as our father ?JANET , who is cutting a slice of bread , stops and looks from one to the other .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: To CARVE .Albert , do n't you know me ? To think that next Tuesday it 'll be six and twenty years since you walked out o ’ the house casual like and — and —Stops from emotion .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Go on . Go on .... To think that I was once shy !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To MRS. SHAWN .Here , you 'd better come and sit a bit nearer the fire .Very kindly .Come along now !

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Obeying .Thank you , m 'm .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To JOHN .And which of you boys was it that had the idea of keeping a middle-aged woman perishing on a doorstep before daylight in February ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How else could we —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Interrupting him .Excuse me , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Subsiding .I beg your pardon , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: To JANET .All questions should be addressed to me . My brother John is here solely to take charge of our mother . We have done our best , by careful forethought , to ensure that this painful interview shall be as brief and as dignified as possible .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And could n't you think of anything cleverer than to give your poor mother her death of cold for a start ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: How else could we have arranged it ? I myself rang at your door for a quarter of an hour yesterday afternoon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: We never heard you .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Strange !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: No , it is n't . We took the bell off three days ago .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I was told that it was impossible to effect an entrance in the ordinary way . Hence , we had to use craft . I argued that food must come into the house , and that it probably came in early .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , it 's a good thing for you I happened to hear the cat mewing , or you might have had another couple of hours in my back yard . You 're the eldest , I suppose .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: We are twins .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: As you say — really !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I am the older , but the difference between us is not considerable .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now , mother , please do n't cry .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Having poured out a cup of tea , holds it before MRS. SHAWN .Sugar ?MRS. SHAWN signifies an affirmative — JANET drops sugar into cup , which MRS. SHAWN takes .You 'll drink it easier if you lift your veil .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Now , mother — you are sure you recognise this gentleman ?

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Not very positively .Yes — yes . It 's a rare long while ....

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: He is your husband and our father ?

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: More positively .Yes . And sorry I am to say it .JANET eyes her carefully .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I think that suffices .To JANET .Madam , you are in a most unfortunate position . You supposed yourself to be a married woman , whereas you are nothing of the kind . I need n't say that as the victim of a heartless bigamist you have our deepest ....

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Handing him a slice of bread on toasting-fork .Just toast this for your mother , will you , and mind the bars . I 'll get another cup or two .Goes to sideboard and gets crockery .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And so these are my two sons ! They show little emotion in beholding the author of their being for the first time . As for me , I hardly recognise them .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: And is it likely , seeing they were born six months after you deserted me , Albert ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I see . If it is n't indiscreet , am I a grandfather ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Toasting .No , sir .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I only wanted to know the worst . Silly joke about the fertility of curates — you 've met with it , no doubt !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Your tone is simply lamentable , sir .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To JAMES .Mind ! You can do the other side . Now , take care ; the fire 's very hot .In the same mild tone to MRS. SHAWN .Twenty-six years , you say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Yes . Albert was twenty-two then , were n't you , Albert ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Undoubtedly .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And how did you come to find us out at last ?

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: It was through an advertisement put in the paper by that Mr. Texel — him that 's in this law case — offering a reward for information about a Mr. Albert Shawn who 'd been valet to that artist man that died .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh ! So Mr. Texel has been advertising , has he ?Giving a cup of tea to JOHN SHAWN .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Yes , for anybody that knew Albert Shawn when he was young . “ Albert Shawn , ” I says , “ that 's my husband 's name . ” I 'd been told he 'd gone off in service with a painter or something of that kind . I married him as a valet .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Pouring out tea .A valet ?

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: A valet , ma'am .... And the struggle I 've had to bring up my children .Whimpering .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Now , mother !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stopping JAMES .That will do now ! Give it me .Taking toast and fork .Here 's some tea . Now do n't pretend you 've never seen a cup of tea before — you a curate !

div.stage: JAMES accepts tea .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Yes , they would go into the church , both of them ! I do n't know how we 've managed it , but managed it we have , surplices and all . And very happy they were , I 'm sure . And now there 's this dreadful scandal . Oh , Albert , you might at least have changed your name ! I — I ——Partially breaks down .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mother , I beg ——MRS. SHAWN breaks down entirely .Mother , I absolutely insist . You know you promised not to speak at all except in answer to questions .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I think , mother , you really might try ——

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Leave her to me ! Now , mother !

div.stage: Loud double knock off .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To JOHN SHAWN .There 's the post ! Just go and bring me the letters in , will you ?JOHN hesitates ?You 'll find them scattered about the floor in the hall . Do n't miss any .

div.stage: Exit JOHN SHAWN , R .
MRS. SHAWN recovers .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: And what do you propose to do , madam ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Who has been soothing MRS. SHAWN .Me ? What about ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: About this — this bigamy .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , nothing . What are you thinking of doing ?

div.stage: Re-enter JOHN SHAWN with post , which CARVE takes and begins to read .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , I suppose you 're aware that bigamy is a criminal offence ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: There 's a police-station in the Upper Richmond Road . Better call there . It 'll be so nice for you two , when you 're flourishing about in the pulpit , to think of your father in prison — wo n't it now ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: We , of course , should not prosecute . If you are prepared to go on living with this gentleman as though nothing had happened —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh , I do n't mind .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , then , I doubt if we should interfere . But Mr. Texel 's lawyers are already in communication with the police .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Stiffly .I see .An awkward pause during which everybody except CARVE , who is reading his post , looks at everybody else .Well , then , I think that 's about all , is n't it ?A shorter pause .Good-morning .She bows to the curates , and shakes hands with MRS. SHAWN .To MRS. SHAWN .Now do take care of yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. S
sp.p: Weakly .Thank you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-morning . Mother , take my arm , please .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Good-morning .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Albert , they 're going .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Looking up absently and only half rising , perfunctorily and quicklyGood-morning . Good-morning .Sits down .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To JAMES SHAWN , who is hovering near door L , uncertain of his way out .This way , this time !

div.stage: Exeunt the SHAWNS followed by JANET .
CARVE rises and draws curtains of window apart
Re-enter JANET .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: CheerfullyOh , it 's quite light !Turns out gas .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Gazing at her .Incomparable woman !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: So it 's true after all !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: All that rigmarole about you being Ilam Carve ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: You 're beginning to come round at last ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I think they were quite honest people — those three . There 's no doubt the poor creature once had a husband who did run off . And it seems fairly clear his name was Albert Shawn , and he went away as valet to an artist . But then , on the other hand , if there is one thing certain in this world , it is that you were never married before you married me . That I will swear to .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And yet she identified me . She was positive .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Positive ? That 's just what she was n't ! And did n't you notice the queer way she looked at you as they went out ? As much as to say , “ I wonder now whether it is him — after all ? ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Then you really think she could be mistaken on such a point ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Pooh ! After twenty-six years . Besides , all men of forty-seven look more or less alike .... And so I 'm the wife of Ilam Carve that 's supposed to be buried in Westminster Abbey and royalty went to his funeral ! We 'll have some tea ourselves . I say , why did you do it ?Pours out tea .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Casually .I do n't know . It was to save worry to begin with , and then it went on by itself and somehow I could n't stop it .... I do n't know !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Endearingly .Well , I 've always told you frankly you 've got a bee in your bonnet .Drinking tea and turning over the post .More letters from these newspaper people ! What 's this lovely crest on this envelope ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: It 's from Lord Leonard Alcar . He says if we 'll go up and see him to-morrow afternoon he 'll be very much obliged indeed , and he may be able to be of assistance to us .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Deeply impressed .Lord Leonard Al ... Where 's the letter ?Searches for it hurriedly . As she reads it .Well I never !Reading“ And Mrs. Shawn . ” I 've got nothing to go in .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh , I sha n't go !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , what about this trip to the Continent ?

lg.l: Continent fiddlesticks . I 've never been asked to go and see a
Lord before ....

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Now listen , Jane . What earthly good can it do ? I sha n't go .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I shall . So there ! Six Dukes in the family ! I would n't miss it for anything .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE I

stage.stage: LORD LEONARD ALCAR 'S study , Grosvenor Gardens . Door , back centre . Door , L. JANET 'S portrait is conspicuous on a wall .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: — The next afternoon . LORD LEONARD ALCAR and MR. TEXEL are coming into the room from door at back .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: You still go on collecting , Mr. Texel ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Uncertain of his steps .Well , yes . I 've been amusing myself with pictures for pretty nigh forty years . Why should I deprive myself of this pleasure merely because my eyesight 's gone ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Why , indeed ! You have the true collecting spirit . Permit medirects Texel 's hand to chair

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Thanks , I 'm on to itSitting down .My sight 's going steadily worse , but there are still a few things that I can make out pretty clearly , Lord Leonard . Motor omnibuses , cathedrals , English easy-chairs ....

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Well , I 'm charmed to find you in such good spirits , and really I feel very grateful to you for accepting my invitation .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Delighted to make your acquaintance , sir . Two old collectors like us — rivals at Christie 's . I wonder how many times I 've cabled over instructions to my agent to smash you at any cost . Delighted to meet you , Lord Leonard .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: We ought to have met earlier , Mr. Texel . Now I 've got you here , I must tell you I 've ventured to invite one or two — er — kindred spirits to meet you .

div.stage: Enter SERVANT .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Mr. Ebag .

div.stage: Enter EBAG .
Exit SERVANT ) .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: How d'you do , Ebag ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: My lord .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Let me introduce you to Mr. Texel . Mr. Texel , this is Mr. Ebag .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Surprised — aside to LORD LEONARD ALCAR .This one of your kindred spirits ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Also surprised ?Mr. Texel !

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Holding out his hand towards EBAG , who takes it .Well , Mr. Ebag , I 've made a special journey to Europe to get a verdict from an English court that you 've done me up for about thirty thousand dollars , and if I get it I 'll do my level best afterwards to see you safe into prison ; but in the meantime I 'm very glad to meet you . I feel sure you 're one of the right sort , whatever you are .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: You flatter me , Mr. Texel . The gladness is mutual .

div.stage: Enter SERVANT .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Mr. Cyrus Carve . Mr. and Mrs. X .

div.stage: Enter JANET . She hesitates in doorway . LORD LEONARD ALCAR goes to meet her .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You Lord Alcar ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I am Lord Leonard Alcar ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: My mistake !They shake hands .But why does this young man call me Mrs. X. I told him Carve , plain enough .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Did he ? A slip — a slip ! You 've brought your husband ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes , but not so easily as all that . I 'm afraid he 's quarrelling out there with Mr. Cyrus Carve . They get across one another on the stairs .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Tut-tut . Excuse me one moment .

div.stage: Exit hurriedly .
Exit SERVANT .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Mr. Ebag ! So you 're here too ! Why , it 's a family party .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Astounded .How do you do , Mrs. Shawn ? I beg pardon , Mrs . Carve .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: It seems I 'm Mrs. X now — did n't you hear ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I expect the servant had received instructions . His lordship has a great reputation for wit , you know .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Looking round .And what 's this room supposed to be ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Oh , the study , probably .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Really ! Not what you 'd call ‘ homely , ’ is it ? Rather like being on the stage .

div.stage: Enter LORD LEONARD ALCAR , leading CARVE on his right and CYRUS on his left . Servant closes door from without .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Now we 're all safely here , and I fancy there will be enough easy-chairs to go round . Mr. Texel , you already know Mr. Cyrus Carve , and you will be pleased to meet the talented artist who painted the pictures which you have been buying from Mr. Ebag . He has most kindly consented to be called Mr. X for the moment . This is Mrs. X , Mr. Texel .

div.stage: They bow — CYRUS shakes hands with TEXEL .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: To CYRUS .How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Observing that these three are already acquainted .Good ! Excellent ! Now , Mrs .— er — X , will you have this chair near the fire ?Fixes chair for her .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Indicating JANET , aside to EBAG .Good looking ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Aside to TEXEL .Very agreeable little thing !

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Excellent ! Excellent !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Interrupting a gesture from CARVE .You have all done me a signal favour by coming here . In thanking you , I wonder if I may ask another favour . May I ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Certainly . Among kindred spirits .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Assuredly , my lord .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I would merely request you to control so far as possible any expression of your astonishment at meeting one another here . That is to say , any violent expression .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Gaily and carelessly .Oh , very well ! Very well !

div.stage: LORD LEONARD ALCAR waves the rest of the company into chairs , tactfully separating CYRUS and CARVE as much as possible . He remains standing himself .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I suppose what you really want is to stop this funny trial from coming on .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Slightly taken aback .Mrs. X , I congratulate myself on your presence here . Yes , my ambition is to be peacemaker . Of course a peacemaker always runs the risk of a broken head , but I shall entrust my head to your good nature . As a proof that I really mean business , I need only point out that I have n't invited a single lawyer .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: After slight pause .This is exceedingly good of your lordship .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: For myself I 'm rather looking forward to next week . I 've spared no expense to get up a first-class show . Half the papers in New York and Chicago are sending over special correspondents . I 've even secured your champion humorous judge ; and altogether I reckon this trial will be about the greatest judicial proposition the British public 's seen in years . Still , I 'm always ready to oblige — and I 'll shake hands right now , on terms — my terms .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: We are making progress .

lg.l: But what I do n't understand is — where you come in , Lord
Leonard .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Where I come in ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Well , I do n't want to be personal , but is this Hague Conference merely your hobby , or are you standing in with somebody ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I quite appreciate your delicacy . Let me assure you that , though it gives me the greatest pleasure to see you all , I have not selected you as the victims of a hobby . Nor have I anything whatever to gain by stopping the trial . The reverse . At the trial I should probably have a seat on the bench next to a delightful actress , and I should enjoy the case very much indeed . I have no doubt that even now the learned judge is strenuously preparing his inimitable flashes of humour , and that , like the rest of the world , I should allow myself to be convulsed by them . I like to think of four K. C . ' s toiling hard for a miserable hundred guineas a day each . I like to think of the solicitors , good , honest fellows , striving their best to keep the costs as low as possible . I even like to think of the jury with their powerful intellects who , when we are dead and gone , Mr. Texel , will tell their grandchildren proudly how they decided the famous case of Texel v. Ebag . Above all , I like to think of the witnesses revelling in their cross-examination . Nobody will be more sorry than I to miss this grand spectacle of the greatest possible number of the greatest possible brains employed for the greatest possible length of time in settling a question that an average grocer 's assistant could settle in five minutes . I am human . But , I have been approached — I have been flattered by the suggestion — that I might persuade you two gentlemen to abandon the trial , and I may whisper to you that the abandonment of the trial would afford satisfaction in — er — influential quarters .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Then are we up against the British Government ? Well , go ahead .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Protesting with a very courteous air of extreme astonishment .My dear Mr. Texel , how can I have been so clumsy as to convey such an idea ? The Government ? Not in the least — not in the least . On behalf of nobody whatever .Confidentially .I am merely in a position to inform you positively that an amicable settlement of the case would be viewed with satisfaction in influential quarters .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , I can tell you it would be viewed with satisfaction in a certain street in Putney . But influential quarters — what 's it got to do with them ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I shall be quite frank with you . The dignity of Westminster Abbey is involved in this case , and nothing in all England is more sacred to us than Westminster Abbey . One has only to pronounce the word “ the Abbey ” — to realize that . We know what a modern trial is ; we know what the modern press is ; and , unhappily , we know what the modern bench is . It is impossible to contemplate with equanimity the prospect of Westminster Abbey and its solemnities being given up to the tender mercy of the evening papers and a joking judge surrounded by millinery . Such an exhibition would be unseemly . It would soil our national existence . In a word , it would have a bad effect .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Meditatively — bland .How English !He gets up and walks unobtrusively about the room , examining the pictures .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Undoubtedly . But this is England . It is perhaps a disadvantage that we are not in Russia nor in Prussia . But we must make the best of our miserable country .In a new tone , showing the orator skilled in changes of voice .Ca n't we discuss our little affair in a friendly way entirely without prejudice ? We are together here , among gentlemen —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're forgetting me .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Recovering himself .Madam , I am convinced that none of us can be more gentlemanly than yourself .... Can we not find a way of settlement ?With luxurious enjoyment of the idea .Imagine the fury of all those lawyers and journalists when they learn that we — er — if I may so express it — have done them in the eye !

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: If I was n't going to come out on top , I could understand you worrying about your old Abbey . But I 'm taking the part of your Abbey . When I win it wins , and I 'm certain to win .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I do not doubt ——

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: With suave assurance .But I do .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Continuing .I do not doubt your conviction , Mr. Texel . It merely proves that you have never seen a British Jury exercising itself upon a question relating to the fine arts . If you had you would not be certain , for you would know that twelve tradesmen so occupied are capable of accomplishing the most incredible marvels . Supposing you do n't win — supposing Mr. Ebag wins ——

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: As I assuredly shall .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Then we should have the whole world saying , “ Well , they have n't given a national funeral to a really great artist for about a century , and when at last they do try they only succeed in burying a valet . ”

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Looking round casually .England all over !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: The effect would be lamentable — utterly lamentable . You will realize that in influential quarters ——

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: But do you reckon this policy of hushing up things ever does any good ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: My dear sir , it is the corner-stone of England 's greatness . It is the policy that has made her what she is !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Looking round again .True ! What she is !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Turning sharply to CARVE behind him .Mr. X , your interest in my picture flatters me immensely ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Interrupting him .I see you 've bought my latest portrait of my wife .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Starting up .What 's that ?She goes to inspect picture .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I suppose it would be abusing your hospitality to inquire how much you paid our excellent dealer for it ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Not in the least . But the fact is we have n't yet settled the price . The exact price is to depend on the result of our gathering .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , if anybody had told me I should find my own portrait — cooking-sleeves and all ——

div.stage: Inarticulate — she returns to her chair .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: And now that we have got so far , Mr. X , I should like to centralize the attention of this quite friendly gathering on yourself .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Approaching airily .Really !He sits .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: There are several questions we might discuss . For example , we might argue the artistic value of the pictures admittedly the work of Mr. X . That would probably occupy us for about ten years . Or we might ask ourselves how it happened that that exceedingly astute dealer , Mr. Ebag , came to sell as a genuine Ilam Carve , without offering any explanation , a picture which , on the face of it , was painted some time after that great painter had received a national funeral in Westminster Abbey .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Sheer carelessness , my lord .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Or we might ask ourselves why a valet should try to pass himself off as a world-renowned artist . Or , on the other hand , why a world-renowned artist should pass himself off as a valet .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Sheer carelessness , my lord .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: But these details of psychology are beside the main point . And the main point isto CARVE— Are you Ilam Carve or are you Albert Shawn ?To the others .Surely with a little goodwill and unembarrassed by the assistance of experts , lawyers , and wigs generally , we can settle that ! And once it is settled the need for a trial ceases .CARVE assumes an elaborately uninterested air .The main point does not seem to interest you , Mr. X .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Seeming to start .I beg your pardon . No , not profoundly . Why should it ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Yet you claim ——

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Excuse me . I claim nothing except to be let alone . Certainly I do not ask to be accepted as Ilam Carve . I was leading a placid and agreeable existence in a place called Putney , an ideal existence with a pearl among women , when my tranquillity was disturbed and my life transformed into a perfect nightmare by a quarrel between a retail trades-manindicating EBAGand a wholesale ink-dealerindicating TEXELabout one of my pictures . It does not concern me . My role is and will be passive . If I am forced into the witness-box I shall answer questions to the worst of my ability , and I shall do no more . I am not cross . I am not sulking ; but I consider that I have a grievance . If I am here , it is solely because my wife does what she likes with me .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Bravo ! This is as good as the trial .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Will you answer questions here ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Good-humouredly .It depends .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Do you assert that you are Ilam Carve ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I assert nothing .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Are you Ilam Carve ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Yes , but I do n't want to be .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Might I inquire why you allowed your servant to be buried in your name ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
