sp.p: Well , he always did everything for me — a most useful man .... But I did n't ‘ allow ’ him to be buried in my name . On the contrary , I told various people that I was not dead — but strange to say , nobody would believe me . My handsome , fascinating cousin here would n't even let me begin to tell him . Even my wife would n't believe me , so I gave it up .

div.stage: TEXEL does not conceal his enjoyment of the scene .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Grimly .Which wife ?

div.stage: CARVE twiddles his thumbs .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: But do you mean ——

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: May I interrupt , Lord Leonard ? I could listen for hours to this absolutely stupendous gentleman . A circus is nothing to it . But are n't we jumping the track ? I 've got two witnesses . Mr. Cyrus Carve will swear that your Mr. X is not his cousin . And the original Mrs. Albert Shawn will swear that he is her husband . That 's my case . How is my esteemed opponent going to answer it ?

lg.l: In the first place , have you cross-examined this very original
Mrs. Albert Shawn ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Come . You do n't mean to argue that a woman could mistake another man for her own husband — even after twenty-five years or so ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Smiling apologetically for his freedom .According to the divorce reports , they 're constantly doing it after one year , to say nothing of twenty-five .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Appreciative .Good ! That 's good ! Well , I may tell you right here that I had an interview with this gentleman 'sindicating CARVEecclesiastical twins only yesterday afternoon , and they assure me that their mother is positive on the point .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Meditatively .Simpletons !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I beg pardon .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I daresay they preach very nicely , but out of the pulpit they do n't what I should call shine , poor boys ! Anybody could see she was n't positive . Why , it was n't until the old lady dropped in to have a cup of tea with us that I felt sure my husband 's name really was Carve .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Then you had n't credited his story before ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Well , it wanted some crediting , did n't it ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: With intention .You only began to credit it after Mr. Ebag had called and paid you the sum of £ 500 in cash .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: After a slight pause , calmly .Oh ! So you know about that , do you ?

lg.l: Cousin , if you continue in that strain
I shall have to take you out on to the doormat and assault you .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I should like to say ——

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Interrupting grimly .Lord Leonard , is n't it time that this ceased ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Heartily amused .But why ? I 'm enjoying every minute of it .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I should be sorry to interfere with Mr. Texel 's amusement , but I think the moment has now come for me to make a disclosure . When I was approached as to this affair I consulted Mr. Cyrus Carve first , he being the sole surviving relative of his cousin . That seemed to me to be the natural and proper course to adopt . Mr. Cyrus Carve gave me a very important piece of information , and it is solely on the strength of that information that I have invited you all to come here this afternoon .He looks at CYRUS .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Clearing his throat , to EBAG and CARVE .Of course , you 'll argue that after thirty-five years absence it 's a wise man that can recognize his own cousin . I 'm absolutely convinced in my own mind that youscorn-fully to CARVEare not my cousin . But then , you 'll tell me that men have been hung before now on the strength of sworn identification that proved afterwards to be mistaken . I admit it . I admit that in theory I may be wrong .With increased grim sarcasm .I admit that in theory the original Mrs. Shawn may be wrong . Everything 's possible , especially with a bully of a K. C . cross-examining you , and a judge turning you into ‘ copy ’ for Punch . But I 've got something up my sleeve that will settle the whole affair instantly , to the absolute satisfaction of both plaintiff and defendant .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: My dear fellow , why not have told us this exciting news earlier ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Why not ?Glowering at CARVE .Because I wanted you to commit yourself completely beyond any withdrawing . I decided what sort of man you were the moment I first set eyes on you , and when I heard of this law case , I said to myself that I 'd come forward as a witness , but I should n't give any evidence away in advance . I said to myself I 'd show you up once and for all in full court . However , his lordship prevailed on me .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: When my cousin and I were boys I 've seen him with his shirt off .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: True . And he 's seen you with yours off .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Now just herepointing to left front neck below collar, just below his collar , my cousin Ilam Carve had two moles close together — one was hairy and the other was n't . My cousin was very proud of them .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Ferociously sarcastic .I suppose you 'll say you 've had them removed ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Casually .No . Not precisely .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Can you show them ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Very casually .Of course .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Slapping his knee .Great ! Great !

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Staggered but obstinate .Well , let 's have a look at them .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: To JANET .Then doubtless you are familiar with this double phenomenon , Mrs. X ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Yes . But he is n't so proud of his moles now as he used to be when he was a boy .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Now , gentlemen , you see how beautifully clear the situation is . By one simple act we shall arrive at a definite and final result , and we shall have avoided all the noise and scandal of a public trial . Mr. X , will you oblige us very much by taking your collar off ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Jumping up .Please , there 's just one little thing .To CARVE .Wait a moment , dear .To EBAG .Mr. Ebag , how many of those pictures did you sell to Mr. Texel ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Fifteen .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: And you made a profit of over four hundred pounds on each ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Boisterously — laughing to EBAG .You did ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Fifteen times four hundred — that makes — how much does it make ?

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Six thousand , madam . Thirty thousand dollars . Great !

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: To EBAG .Do n't you think we deserve some of that , as it were ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Madam , I shall be delighted to pay you five thousand four hundred pounds . That will be equivalent to charging you a nominal commission of ten per cent .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I wo n't touch a penny of their wretched money .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sweetly .I would n't dream of asking you to , dearest . I shall touch it . Goodness knows what street we shall be in after this affair — and with my brewery shares gone simply all to pieces ! Now , dearest , you can take it off .She resumes her seat .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lightly .I 'm hanged if I do !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: But , my dear Mr. X !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Lightly .I 'm dashed if I take my collar off .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Triumphant .Ha ! I knew it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Why should I offer my skin to the inspection of two individuals in whom I have n't the slightest interest ? They 've quarrelled about me , but is that a reason why I should undress myself ? Let me say again , I 've no desire whatever to prove that I am Ilam Carve .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: But surely to oblige us immensely , Mr. X , you will consent to give just one extra performance of an operation which , in fact , you accomplish three hundred and sixty-five times every year without any disastrous results .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: I do n't look at it like that . Already my fellow-citizens , expressing their conviction that I was a great artist , have buried me in Westminster Abbey — not because I was a great artist , but because I left a couple of hundred thousand pounds for a public object . And now my fellow-citizens , here assembled , want me to convince them that I am a great artist by taking my collar off . I wo n't do it . I simply will not do it . It 's too English . If any person wishes to be convinced that I 'm an artist and not a mountebank , let him look at my workpointing vaguely to a picture, because that 's all the proof that I mean to offer . If he is blind or shortsighted I regret it , but my neck is n't going to help him .

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Brilliant ! Then we shall have the trial after all .

lg.l: Yes , but your brilliant friend will be on his way to South
America before then .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Sweetly to CYRUS .I assure you it 's quite true about those moles . That 's why he wears those collars .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Grimly .No doubt ....Repeating .Nevertheless he 'll be on his way to South America .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Gaily .Or Timbuctoo .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: Significantly .Unless you 're stopped .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: And who 's going to stop me ? All the laws of this country added together can n't make me take my collar off if I do n't want to .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: What about arresting you for bigamy ? What about Holloway ? I fancy at Holloway they have a short method with people who wo n't take their collars off .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Well , that will only be another proof that the name of this island is England . It will be telegraphed to the Continent that in order to prove to herself that she possessed a great artist , England had to arrest him for bigamy and shove him into prison .... Characteristic ! Characteristic !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Who has moved across to JANET .Mrs. X , can you —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Rising to CARVE , winningly .Now — Ilam . You 're only laying up trouble for yourself , and for me too . Do please think of the trial . You know how shy you are , and how you tremble at the mere thought of a witness-box .

sp.speaker: CYRUS
sp.p: I can believe it .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Smiling at JANET .I 've got past shyness . I think it was the visit of my fine stalwart sons yesterday that cured me of shyness . I doubt if I shall ever be shy any more .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Appealingly .Dearest , to please me !

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Curt now for the first time , with a flash of resentment .No .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: After a slight pause ; hurt and startled ; with absolute conviction , to LORD LEONARD ALCAR .It 's no use . He 's made up his mind .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I have an idea that I can persuade —

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Hotly .Excuse me . You can n't .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: I have an idea I can . Buthesitatesthe fact is , not in the presence of ladies .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Oh . If that 's all —walks away in a huff .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: To JANET .My deepest apologies .

div.stage: LORD LEONARD ALCAR shows JANET out

sp.speaker: TEXEL
sp.p: Well , well ! What now ?

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: To CARVE .You remember Lady Alice Rowfant ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: Taken aback .That does n't concern you .

sp.speaker: EBAG
sp.p: Ignoring this answer .Pardon me if I speak plainly . You were once engaged to marry Lady Alice Rowfant . But a few days before your valet died you changed your mind and left her in the lurch in Spain . Lady Alice Rowfant is now in England . She has been served with a subpoena to give evidence at the trial . And if the trial comes on she will have to identify you and tell her story in court .Pause .Are you going to put her to this humiliation ?

div.stage: CARVE walks about . Then he gives a gesture of surrender .

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: The artist is always beaten !With an abrupt movement he pulls undone the bow of his necktie .

div.stage: The stage is darkened to indicate the passage of a few minutes .

stage.stage: ( CARVE is attempting to re-tie his necktie . LORD LEONARD ALCAR is coming away from door back . JANET enters from door , L .)

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Under emotion , to CARVE .Then you 've done it !CARVE ignores her .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Yes , and I feel like a dentist .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: You 've sent them all away .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I thought you 'd like me to . Mr. Ebag took charge of Mr. Texel . Your cousin Cyrus was extremely upset .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: What did she say ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Who say ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Lady Alice Rowfant , of course . Oh ! You need n't pretend ! As soon as Mr. Ebag asked me to go out I knew he 'd got her up his sleeve .Weeps slightly .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Very sympathetically .My dear young lady , what is the matter ?

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Her utterance disturbed by sobs — indicating CARVE .He 'd do it for her , but he would n't do it for me !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: I assure you , Lady Alice Rowfant has not been here .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: Honest ?

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: No . The mere mention of her name was sufficient .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: That 's even worse !Rushing across to CARVE and pettishly seizing his necktie . CARVE submits .Here ! Let me do it — for goodness sake ! Great clumsy !Still tearful — to LORD LEONARD ALCAR as she ties the necktie .Somehow I do n't mind crying in front of you , because you 're so nice and fatherly .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Well , if I 'm so fatherly , may I venture on a little advice to you two ?To CARVE .You said you did n't want to be Ilam Carve . Do n't be Ilam Carve . Let Ilam Carve continue his theoretical repose in the Abbey and you continue to be somebody else . It will save a vast amount of trouble , and nobody will be a penny the worse . Leave England — unobtrusively . If you feel homesick , arrange to come back during a general election , and you will be absolutely unnoticed . You have money . If you need more , I can dispose of as many new pictures as you like to send .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I do n't want him to paint any more pictures .

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: But he will .

sp.speaker: JANET
sp.p: I suppose he will . Why is it ? As if we had n't had enough bother already through this art business !

sp.speaker: ALCAR
sp.p: Yes . But artists are like that , you know .

lg.l: Child ! Look how nicely
I 've tied it for you .
Whatever are you dreaming about ?

sp.speaker: CARVE
sp.p: After glancing in mirror reflectively .There 's only one question . Last time they buried me in the Abbey ,— what will they do with me next time ? CURTAIN .
